Dear Sir -

As I supply furnace wood to the Maria Indian day school, I wish to ask you while at Ottawa, will you please try and have a wood shed built, as it is most urgently needed. Ottawa,
April 7, 1942.

Dear Sir:

J. Milton Gedson has written with reference to the erection of a woodshed at the Maria Indian Day School. When this school was originally built it was understood that space for the storing of fuel was provided in the basement. However, I understand that this space is now being used for vocational training purposes. Under these circumstances a woodshed is probably required. We had some correspondence regarding the matter last year and it was estimated that it would cost $275.00 to erect a suitable woodshed.

The Department feels that a woodshed could be erected at much less cost than the figure stated above and I should appreciate your giving the matter some thought and advising me the size of the woodshed required and giving an estimate of its cost. I thought that if the material were supplied the woodshed could be erected very cheaply under your direction. When replying you might let me have a list of the materials which you consider would be needed.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Edgar Arsenault,
Farming Instructor,
Indian Reserve,
Maria, Que.
Ottawa,
April 7, 1942.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Indian Reserve No. 20th, 1942

Mr. Nap. Lynn - Agent

Dear Mr. Lynn:

With reference to the recommendation of 12 desks for the school I beg to inform you that in the elementary classrooms there are only 34 seats for 37 pupils and new pupils are coming in; in the junior class we have 125 seats for 28 pupils not mentioning 8 rooms for special classes 3 times a week.

Placing 3 pupils where they should be two (that is on the double seats) is neither hygienic nor proper. How can they write when they have no place to work?

Of course, in the junior classes 9 of the pupils are not expected to come back in September, but will be replaced by others.

Independent from the number of new pupils 12 of the old two-seat desks are
are shaky and not removable. When we first came here in Sept. 1841, you kindly did your best to repair them but it lasted no time owing to the fact that holes are so rotten and that bolts are somewhat useless. As I said above they are so shaky that to have the children to use them is a problem.

I felt quite shy to ask the Department for twelve desks—and indeed I should have asked for six simple back seats—as we are actually buying chairs at $5 from the class store to the sewing class, but in time I may see they had to with the less desirable; nevertheless if these are added to the number asked for we shall all be satisfied.

Very respectfully Yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant in regard to the benches requested by the Superior of the Convent of the Reserve, I must say that in one classroom there are 34 benches and 37 children; therefore, 3 benches and desks are required. In the higher class, there are 5 double desks which came from the old school and which are in very poor condition. I repaired them myself before the classes opened but they are falling apart again.

The materials may cost about $190.00 to $200.00; it is difficult to say exactly because the wood is getting dearer at present, but I am pretty sure that the list of material needed for this shed will be close of $200.00... perhaps a little more.

For the workship, Mr Napoleon Cyr, the Indian Agent for the Maria reserve would take the job for $75.00, and I do not think it is too much.

Consequently, I am of the opinion that the total amount of $275.00 for the erection of this woodshed, is not exaggerated; it is understood that the cost of the material and the workship is included in the amount of $275.00.

Monsieur Secrétaire,

En réponse à votre lettre du 6 mai, au sujet de la requête que vous avez adressée, je ne peux pas faire, car je ne peux pas être à mon bureau, en les religieuses qui protestent contre les amas faites par le Dr Maclean et il ne la promesse pas que je fasse quelque chose pour les signer. Pour les tomber et le fait qu'il a été dit pour moi ça ne me convient pas.

Bien à vous,

Napoléon Gd
agent indien
Gagné, May 11, 1942.

Mr. Secretary,

Replying to your letter of May 6th, in connection with a requisition which was forwarded to you, I may say that the said requisition was not sent by me; in fact it has not passed through my office. The Sisters probably asked Doctor Maclean to fill same but he has not sent it to me for my signature. When I send requisitions I always sign them. In regard to the tomatoes and milk which were ordered, I do not see any use for those items.

Yours truly,

(signed) Napoléon Cyr,
Indian Agent.
Memorandum for file:

In a requisition dated April, 1942, on file 31-17, the Principal of the Maria Indian Day School made the following request: "A quantity of tomatoes and milk". In a letter dated May 6 the Indian Agent was advised to submit a separate report regarding this request and forward this report to the Training Division. The Indian Agent's reply is attached.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Restigouche, May the 27th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of July the 15th, concerning the water situation at the Maria School, I wish to inform you that I have begun to establish a report to settle this question.

It is not an easy job for me to give a definite recommendation and give the approximate cost for this work.

According to the informations taken till now from those who have worked for the digging of the well, it is the third time that this job is undertaken without good results.

Last year the well has been dug by hand according to a plan suggested by your Department and two months after there was no more water. The well is about 15 feet deep and on my opinion I do not think it is sufficient, on account of the hill and the quick sand in this place.

I do not take any decision at present, but I believe the best way to have water there, is to dig a well about 25 to 30 feet deep with a diamond drill. In this manner the general level would be reached and the coat of quick sand passed.

The reasons of the trouble is certainly the quick sand and if we want to have water, we must dig deep enough to be clear of it.

I will continue to study carefully that question before giving a definite recommendation, and in a couple weeks I will send you my report.

Yours very truly,

Edgar Arsenault, Farming Instructor,
Restigouche, N.B.

Dear Sir:

The present is to inform the Department that I have decided to dig by hand, the well at the Maria Indian School.

After having taken serious informations from "wells diggers" of Caplin and Bonaventure, we came to the conclusion that it would be a great risk to use a diamond drill to dig this well on account of the composition of the ground; and no one could assure me to be able to have water by using a drill in that place.

It is why, I have decided to dig it by hand.

According to the inspection I have done, there is at present a good quantity of water in the well, so it is not the water missing.

My plan is the following:

To dig the well deep enough to assure to have a sufficient quantity of water for the school.

Make the hole 4 feet square and a wall all around with 2 inches thick planks.

In the bottom of the well we will use spruce planks, 2" thick, for a height of 4 feet,... this wood does not give any taste to the water, and the rest of the well till the top will be in cedar planks, 2" thick.

A certain quantity of stones will be placed at the bottom of the well in such a way that they will not intercept the circulation of the water.

The pipe will be placed in the middle of the well at about one foot from the bottom, and strongly braced up at the sides of the well.

A good cover will be made on the top to prevent the falling of the ground, stones or gravel in the well.
Ottawa,

In your letter of October 1st, you state that the needs of the Maria Indian Day School should be brought to the attention of the Department by the agent and not by a Member of Parliament.

It is exactly my opinion, and may I point out, that since I am working for your Department, I have never written to the Member to help me in any case concerning my work, but I have always tried to do it myself with the collaboration of the Department.

Moreover, when the Father Roussel and the Principal of the School asked me to do a report regarding the pupil Francis Gedeon to send him to college, I never wrote to the Member to do this request, but I have done it myself according to the judgment I had on the pupil.

As the Department told me in the letter of October the 1st, the Principal of the Maria School has been advised to submit to the agent the needs of the school.

Dear Sir:

I am requested by the Principal of the Maria Indian Day School, to ask the Department authorization of an amount of $65.00 to improve the heating plan in the south room where the Sisters are taking their meals.

The heating grate there is in this room is not sufficient to furnish a convenient warmth.

The grate is placed in the wall at about 5 feet high and consequently, the floor is always very cold.

It is to improve the conditions of the floor that this request is presented to the Department.

Kind Mr. Hoye,

You probably don't know that no porch is attached to the school door and that 40 inches is the only space between it and the steps which lead to the classroom. The consequence is that the pupils coming in crowd, all snowed up, jam at the door, trying to shake off the snow and being obliged to keep the door opened too long a time, the heat goes out and the cold comes in. Should a side building be attached to that side of the house it would serve both to the pupils entrance and to a kitchen for the Sisters. As it is now in the kitchenette the pump is exactly 20 inches from the cupboard, at the other end just the place for the door to open. Sideways there are 5 feet between the table adjusted to the partition and the sink. The reservoir being only 2 X 4 ft. the janitor has to pump several times a day and then the cook is delayed in her work being unable to take the necessary things in the cupboard - pantry which is but one - the "pumper" filling up the space between it and the pump.

All this is submitted to your kind attention and we shall be grateful and satisfied for anything you grant us remembering how kindly you have treated us so far.

Sister M of Mercy, Principal.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I attach account amounting to $169.21, covering the cost of lumber purchased for the erection of a chicken house at the Maria Indian Day School. This Branch was anxious to encourage the raising of chickens on the Maria Reserve and the Sisters in charge of the school were willing to undertake the work under the supervision of the Farming Instructor, Mr. Edgar Arsenault. The latter was written with reference to the erection of the chicken house and without further authority he proceeded to purchase the materials required. This account covers the cost of these materials. When he was requested to explain why he purchased the materials without authority he stated that he had had an opportunity of purchasing the lumber at a very reasonable cost. Schools;

Maria; I noticed that a new poultry house had been erected by the Department, and the same should help to increase poultry raising on this reserve.

There are also two other small buildings erected, one being near the school house side entrance; the sister superior said they had to build it themselves because there is not sufficient accommodation in their kitchen for storage of food and supplies; this small building is no doubt required for additional space but is not improving the general appearance of our school. The other building is larger and erected just outside of the school grounds close to our fence and is used as storage for the sisters' trunks and also for some old clothing sent for distribution to the Indians.

However, and in spite of extra expenditure incurred since the sisters have taken charge, I must admit a noticeable change in the children and the activities of Rev. Roussel, are helping much towards the improvement of morals on this reserve.

Restigouche, February the 22nd, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Stove for Cooking Class, Maria Ind. School.

Enclosed please find a letter from Sister Mary of Mercy, Principal of the Maria Indian Day School, asking authority for the purchase of a stove ($65.00) for the use of the Cooking Class in the basement of the School.

At my last visit at the School, I have examined the old stove bought by the Principal few years ago, and I may assure the Department that it is done and dangerous for the fire.

I recommend the purchase of a new stove in order to be able to continue the cooking class for the pupils and also to give sufficient heat in the basement.

As there is only one stove to sell at Maria, an immediate answer would be very much appreciated. With thanks,

Edgar Arsenault, Actg. Ind. Agent.

Very respectfully,

Sr. M. J. St. Adeline

Mr. E. Arsenault, Indian Agent, Restigouche, Que.

I am in receipt of a letter from Sister St. Adeline of the Maria School requesting eleven desks. School desks are made in three sizes, large, medium and small. Please let me know which sizes are required.

Mr. Morris' report dated Oct-10-11 on Restigouche Agency

Returning from New Carlisle in the afternoon a short visit was made at the Maria Reserve.

SCHOOL - two-room with teacher's residence attached. The building was in a neat and clean condition.

The agent was authorized to order a new water tank in the attic that was no longer serviceable. The emergency purchase was necessary because it supplies water to the hot water tank connected to the furnace which would be damaged unless action was taken immediately.

ATTENTION - MR. PHILAN. The toilets at the school were in a filthy condition and located too close to the school. Arrangements were made to obtain a small piece of ground - a width of about 20 feet - back of the school lot from Mrs. Louis Levine Martin to locate the toilets a greater distance from the school. Agent Arsenault was instructed to build new seats, move the toilets, and then place the fence back to include the new area. Note, Mrs. Martin is over 90 years of age and receiving a ration costing approximately $10.00 per month. Her ration is to be increased to $12.00 per month for making this small stretch of land available.

Ottawa, December 5th, 1945.

Rev. Sister M. of St. Adeline, Principal, Maria Indian Day School, Dimock Creek, Que.,

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo and I have taken careful note of its contents.

I have studied the plans which we have here but apparently some minor changes must have been made during the construction. I notice by the plans that there are no doors in the classroom and that these openings are wider than the opening of the door leading to the hallway. This would require framing. I wish, therefore, to have an estimate of the cost of this work including labour and material. I wish also to draw your attention to the fact that this will bring the two doors close to each other, both openings on the inside which should be avoided whenever possible. Would there be any other way in which this nuisance could be avoided or diminished?

After receiving this information I will be able to give this matter further consideration.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch,

Replying to your letter of the 25th inst., in connection with the Maria Indian Day School, I wish to give the following information:

The first time the pump went out of order the sisters asked my authority to hire an Indian to do the repairs, which was granted; a few weeks later, again the sisters reported the pump out of order, that time I went down and hired a man who done the repairs under my supervision. Together we examined the well in order to find a solution to prevent the dampness which is causing mouldiness around the side of the well. We have decided to install a 3" pipe from the top into the well in order to give ventilation.

As for the teachers carrying water from the neighbours for the pupils, I am not ready to digest such statement, because I have given authority to the sisters, to the principal to hire a man to carry water and I have suggested to take the junior until the well was fixed, therefore if the sisters carried water they did it on their own and should not register this as a complaint.

I understand that the Dept. gave authority for an expenditure of about $31.90 for installing sinks & sewage at this school. Since this date, every effort has been done to find the necessary material to perform the work, I have been fortunate to find the sink & double tub, but it is impossible to find the 4" pipe we need for the sewage, nevertheless I have good hope to locate the necessary material to install the sink with hot and cold water, now to the end of the week.

The new sewage that we have to build will be done only next spring on account of the reasons mentioned above, lack of material. For this fall the sink will be connected to the old sewage. The expense
for the cleaning of the well and the ventilator will be charged on the amount of $321.90 already authorized. I presume that all these expenditures may be classified as Re: water system.

I wish to point out that the water was inspected last year by an official of the Health Unit Office New-Carlisle and the test proved that the water was potable. When the sisters complained about the taste of the water, my first thought was that it could be due to the natural taste of water in different district, but on the second complaint I went down the cellar and opened the well in order to find the cause.

We came to the conclusion that it was due to the mouldiness caused by the dampness. As stated in previous paragraphs steps are being taken to overcome this situation.

Hoping these informations will be to your satisfaction.

E. Arseneault
(E. Arseneault)
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Digging Well Maria Indian Day School.

Referring to your letter dated June 28th, in connection with the digging of a well for the Maria Indian Day School, I wish to inform the Dept. that I have met Mr Gabriel Arsenault, well digger of the Bonaventure district, and according to his experience, it is impossible to give an estimate for the digging of a well.

It depends on the sort of ground, soft or rock, deepness of the rock, deepness of the water etc., etc.

However, Mr Arsenault, is ready to undertake the job at the following conditions:

For digging, himself, one helper and boarding.......2.00 per foot.

Casing, 6", ........2.25 per foot.

There is no other well on the reserve, dugged with drill, all the wells are dugged by hand, and the water is about at 18 feet deep. Without having any experience regarding the digging of wells, I think a deepness of about 40 to 50 feet would be sufficient; though it is not an affirmation. Necessary pipes for inside the casing will have to be bought and also a suction pump.

Would you please authorize immediately (if possible) an approximate amount of $300.00 for the job. Mr Arsenault has many wells to dig at present, but he would be ready to come anytime in August.

Your immediate answer would be appreciated.

Work on the sewage is already started.

E. Arsenault, Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Referring to your letter of September the 22nd, last paragraph, I may say that the suggestion given in the manner of digging and installing the well is certainly good at every point of view.

We have been endeavouring to find cement tile, diameter of about 30 inches since September without success; the best companies and even the Provincial Roads Department have been approached regarding the matter, but one and the other are looking for same for their own use.

On June 10th, accompanied by Mr. E. Arsenault,
Superintendent, Restigouche Indian Agency, Restigouche, P.Q.,
I visited the Maria Reserve and their Day School.

The question of electricity was immediately
taken up by the Sister Superior there, and it seems that the
Co-operative are willing to bring the electricity right to the
School for the amount of $150. This School, I understand, is
already wired and ready to receive the electricity. Due to the
fact that electricity in this School is of great advantage, I
am wondering if your Branch could not do something in order that
the School be furnished electricity by this Co-operative. I
understand that already a lot of correspondence has been exchanged
in this regard, and yet the Superintendent has not received final
authority to go ahead with this project.

Superintendent Arsenault also brought up the question
of the well at the Maria Day School. I suggested that if he used
30" cement pipes he could easily dig a well there with Indian labour
and have sufficient water to furnish the School. This, I think,
would be about the cheapest way, as there does not appear to be
any well diggers around that part of the country. I would, therefore,
suggest that as they are in dire need of a well at this School,
an estimate be made of the cost by Mr. Arsenault and submitted for
your approval.

J. E. Gendron,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies
for Province of Quebec.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Jackson,

Re - Maria Indian Day School, Maria Indian Agency, Province of Quebec.

As you are aware, in the Province of Quebec, co-operative electrical units are established with the cooperation of the Provincial Government. The public put up $25,000.00 by the purchase of co-operative shares. When this amount is obtained the Provincial Government will make available $75,000.00 so that each co-operative unit has a capitalization of $100,000.00.

Non-shareholders cannot obtain electrical service unless there is surplus power. Before His Majesty, in right of Canada, under a co-operative scheme may obtain electric service it must be a shareholder and in this instance it will be necessary that the shares in question be purchased. These should be taken out in the name of His Majesty in right of Canada and upon their issue it will be possible for the Maria School to obtain electric service.

It is therefore suggested that you approve of the attached proposal.

Sept 4, 1948

I have to inform you that we have not received the last Bulletin for June 1948 as soon as we'll get it we will comply with your request.

I will also profit by the same to tell you that no return yet of our last requisition form filled at the beginning of April. We are in great need of schoolmate and we rely on your kindness to see about it.

You must also be aware of the fact that we are starting our third year without water. We would be very grateful to you if you could do something regarding this matter. We truly hope you know what kind of water we drink since two years; we have often exposed our situation to the Honorable Department with no result, and we wonder if really we are...
going to be left without water for another year.

Hoping you'll take the matter in consideration, in trying to improve our situation.

I hope to remain, kind Sir,

yours very respectfully,

Sr. M. J. St. Bernardin, Principal

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa. November 27, 1948.

Re: Water Supply System,
Two Classroom Indian Day School
with Teachers Quarters,
Maria Indian Reserve, Quebec.

This Division was verbally requested on the 19th instant by Mr. A. Doucet of the Indian Affairs Branch, to provide them with a specification for the necessary equipment to provide an automatically controlled electrically powered water system, for the Two Room Indian Day School with Teachers Quarters, accommodating four teachers and eighty students at the above location.

In this connection, Mr. A. Doucet furnished us with the following information concerning the probable water demands and the existing well:

1. 3 sinks and 1 toilet to be served.
2. Well 32" dia. 20' deep, 7' of water test showed well refilled in 20 minutes after being emptied.

Based on that data only, the following is a specification for a pump and pressure tank which should service the school. The cost of this equipment is estimated at $225.00 f.o.b. Ottawa.

(a) One shallow well pump equal to Duro Series 250 No. 360 complete with pressure switch set to operate pump between 20 and 40 lbs, and powered by 110 V. 60 cycle A.C. motor through V Belt drive.

(b) One vertical galvanized welded steel tank 30" dia. 6' high tested to 125 lbs hydrostatic pressure.

This tank shall be equipped with pressure and water gauge and shall have a capacity of 180 Imperial Gallons.

A 1" galvanized steel suction line terminated in a strainer, should be rigidly suspended from the top of well opening and the strainer shall be so placed as to leave 12" clearance from the bottom of the well. The discharge line from the pump to the pressure tank and the main supplying the fixture branches, should be 1" galvanized steel pipe.

Will you kindly furnish Indian Affairs with this information.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attn: Mr. E.F. Neary:

Dear Sir:

Attached please find vouchers covering work done at the Maria Indian Day School, this work having been authorized by Mr. A.J. Doucet, Supervisor of Vocational Training, and by Mr. J.E. Gendron, Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Quebec and New Brunswick.

The work on well, and also covering cement top on man-hole with gravel to prevent breakage was the authorization of Mr. Gendron. Installation of electric pump, changes in lighting of classrooms, together with additional outlets, also doors on classrooms, was authorized by Mr. Doucet, when he last visited the school in November.

The water system seems to be a success, with plenty of good water, the electric pump is working fine, I therefore do not anticipate any further trouble as regards the water supply.

The lighting in the classrooms was not strong enough, there was also a lack of lights in other parts of the building, this has now been remedied.

The doors were a necessity, in that there was no separation between entrance hall and classrooms.

The porch over the front entrance was also a necessity, as after every storm the entrance was blocked up with snow, and, as this door swings outward there were times when it had to be shoveled out before it could be opened, the addition of the porch has cured this.
The work in connection with clogged sewer was undertaken by myself, this being more or less an emergency. I regret to say however that it was not a success, and we will have to have it dug up in the Spring. This apparently was a botch job in the first instance, and from information obtained from one of the men who worked on it, I do not think it will be successful until adjustments are made. I am attaching herewith a sketch which shows point of defect.

I remain, Sir,

Yours very truly

(C.R. Hadeau) Supt.

Sir,

They are solidly constructed from highest grade yellow birch, all joints being tenoned and mortised and strongly bolted. All are finished in natural wood color, highly varnished.

Built for heavy as well as for light work they are very popular for domestic weaving. Everything from heavy rugs to light cloth tissues can be woven with the greatest ease on a "LECLERC" loom. The peacock's tail shape treadle control centers the pull on the harness and thus simplifies the general operation of the loom.

The brake that is fixed to the back beam prevents to keep the exact tight on the warp. It consists of a screw bar running from the front to the rear which acts directly on a steel ring placed around the back beam. The ring being tightened on beam, take up the slack when the cloth is advanced and stop the beam to spread out, but permits to wind the cloth at will. It eliminates the necessity of continually going around to the rear to adjust the warp, what happens when there is no brake.

In setting up the loom the brake is set slack and then tightened as the work progresses.

Looms are shipped assembled except for the two roller supports and pedals which are adjusted ready to be attached to looms. All other accessories are shipped ready to be put into operation.

Dear Sir,

The Teaching Staff for the Academic School Year 1941-1942 have already met your kind appreciation.

Sister Mary of St. Cecilia for Primary Class,
Sister Mary of St. David for Senior Class,
Sister Mary of Mercy Parleval and Teacher of the Domestic Training Class.

We certainly comply with your desire of having the girls trained in Domestic Economy such as weaving, sewing, knitting, cooking and fruit preserving etc., as mentioned in your letter to His Excellency Bishop J.C. Ross of Barrie June 3rd.

You will hereafter find the list of the equipment necessary for such training. Such is the outfit we generally have.
in our household training schools for a limited number of pupils.

Regarding the kitchen outfit, I would be exceedingly grateful if you could send the money to myself so I could choose the proper articles so as to arrange the present needs.

Prices were taken from catalogs in hand and from inquiries made in Campbellton & Mont. Joli shops.

As you understand, I would go myself for the purchase as soon as I receive your grant and I will make everything ready for the opening of school.

If this does not meet your approval kindly let me know and I will be ever ready to meet your will and act accordingly.

I think you know that the first valuable shop here is about three miles from the school and the agent is not quite at hand yet.
For that reason and having no funds whatever, I should greatly appreciate a grant of $10.00 or $15.00 dollars, however money, so I could order by mail.

Very devotedly Yours,

Sister Mary of Mercy Conne

Dear Sister:

I have your letter of the 18th ultimo enclosing requisition for a large amount of supplies for the Maria Indian Day School. While it is true that the Department is desirous of encouraging vocational training at all our schools, and it is evident that you forwarded your requisition with this in mind, I would point out that in the appropriation for the current fiscal year no provision was made for the very heavy expenditure that would be necessary if the articles shown on your requisition were purchased. It is impossible for us to incur expenditures unless the funds have been specifically provided and consequently you will realize that favourable consideration cannot be given to your request at the present time.

There is a further consideration; namely, that as Sisters are only starting in this school this year I believe that it would be preferable to proceed slowly during the academic year 1941-42 as this will give you an opportunity to study the capabilities of the students and you will be in a better position next year to decide what new courses should be followed during the academic year 1942-43.

It has been decided to allow an amount of $40.00 for purchase of materials for plain sewing. You may also purchase 6 pairs of small scissors, 3 pairs of medium sized scissors, 3 measuring

Ottawa, October 28, 1941.

Re: Inspection at Maria Agency

I beg to report on my last inspection on the 21 and 22 instant to the above agency.

SCHOOL

The attendance appears to have improved considerably this year.

The Sisters are preparing to start their course in domestic teaching; a new sewing machine arrived on the day of my visit, and it was most welcomed.

A cesspool was under construction and toilet supplies are expected to be installed within a few days.

The supply of fuel wood had already been delivered and piled on the grounds back of the school; quality of the wood is very good.

As a means of practical teaching of gardening, I recommend this Fall, the ploughing of a corner of the school ground. This will not interfere with playing, as there is plenty of ground left for that purpose. From the Highway fence, twenty feet wide and a depth of about seventy feet along the side fence, will, in my opinion be a good start and the expense light. The purchase of a few garden tools is also recommended for next Spring.

Regarding domestic science, in the girls' room, I have recommended a cupboard to be built, with shelves, to lock away all sewing materials, supplies, etc., as no such provision had been made when the building was erected; a table, about ten feet long by three feet wide is needed to cut cloth and to make over any clothing from army supplies which are being sent to the Agency. The Sisters are most anxious to teach the girls how to make over such clothings.

While I was there, the Agent received permission to purchase chairs for the girls' room in the basement of the school.

May I hope that the Department will approve my recommendations above:

- Ploughing of school garden, this Fall
- Large table for girls' work room (estimated $10.)
- Cupboard in basement (estimated $15.)
- Garden tools for pupils' garden

Agent told me that a requisition was sent about two months ago for rubbers for school children, wool for knitting, etc., but to date, none of these supplies had been received.

Chief Abraham Martin and a few others, complained that they were not on the fuel wood list; they were told to clear up the old wood lot where I was informed, there remains from 65 to 75 loads of wood which could be cut.

November 30, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Mr. A.J. Doucet of the Training Division will reach Campbellton, N.B., on the Ocean Limited at 10:30 a.m. Wednesday, November 25.

I should appreciate it if you would meet him and take him to the Maria Reserve where he intends to spend two or three days.

Mr. Doucet has recently joined the staff of this Branch and was formerly in charge of a large vocational school in Western Canada. He will be able to discuss curriculum with the teachers of the Maria School and make certain suggestions with regard to the Department's desire to have vocational training receive proper attention.

I feel certain that Mr. Doucet's visit will be conducive of much good at the Maria School and I have no doubt that the teachers will carefully consider his suggestions and make every possible effort to put them into active operation.

Following his visit to Maria he will spend two or three days with the teachers of the Restigouche Indian Day School and his work at Restigouche will be along the same lines as at Maria. You should notify the teachers of the Restigouche School accordingly. It will not be necessary for you to advise the teachers of the Maria School as a copy of this letter is being sent to them.

Yours truly,

Dr. A. Richard,
Indian Agent,
Restigouche, Que.

March 6th, 1942

To Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare Training,
Ottawa

Honorable Sir:

I am sending a few samples of the children's work, not that I mean that the work is perfect but to show that those dear little ones are willing to profit by the lessons and training they receive.

Considering that none of them could sew, and that only two knew how to hold knitting needles, you will admit that their application and skill are somewhat remarkable. Mr. Doucet saw the very beginning, I think he will find improvement.

Of course, they have to be guided very closely, but it is only a pleasure to do so when they are willing to learn.

The dresses and other garments are made out...
of old units rent by the Department with the addition of a little trimming.

I wish you could have seen what a job it was to rip, wash, iron and press the material before using it. These baths were hardly sufficient to obtain a decent cleanliness; the task was made harder owing to the fact that we had not the equipment for such work; no washing machine, no tub, no pail or iron. We had to borrow all that which were lent only when the owner did not use them of course.

You know how very much I'm the Maria school this year and you may believe that teachers and pupils are grateful. We have done something also. So many things are needed for a start in order to bring out the work to some success—considering there were only the bare walls when we started the work; we have fitted there some $20.00 of ours. The children being so enthusiastic we thought it a duty to walk in the footsteps of their good will and the moment was propitious to make them understand they ought to do something for themselves and not always depend on the Department. Of course this will be installed little by little.

We have quite a few pieces made and we are willing to prepare some more would the Department find means to provide us with
a couple of tubs and pails and a set of irons
as also a few yards of lining, trimming material
& doz of belt buckles and a few packages of dye.

I don't think money will thereby be ill spent—

It is surprising to see how children and even
parents try to imitate at home what is done
in the sewing class. Some big girls not coming
to school—have asked to follow the course.

Hoping you will not find we are asking too
much and that we are working in the interest
of the Department and thanking you for past favors

I beg to sign,

Your grateful & respectful servant,
Sister Mary of Mercy Boone.

Ottawa,

It is expected that you will purchase these as reasonably as possible. You should obtain the account in triplicate and hand it to Indian Agent Cyr who will attach it to proper voucher forms and forward for payment.

Ottawa,
September 14, 1942.

My dear Sister:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 7, in which you submit a report on the vocational studies undertaken and carried forward by you during the last academic year at the Maria School.

This report, on the whole, is encouraging to the officials here and to myself. We feel that it is impossible to overemphasize the value of vocational instruction and practical training in the courses provided by the Department for Indian boys and girls.

It is my intention to ask the Purchasing Division for a new sewing machine for your school and a certain amount of flannelette will be purchased for you by the Welfare Division. I am anxious that you should do everything humanly possible to encourage the Indians, particularly Indian boys and girls whose parents may be gainfully employed, to make a contribution, no matter how small, to these projects. For example, it might be possible, in some cases, for the Indian parents to purchase the material, on the understanding that the actual task of making dresses or clothing of any kind would be undertaken as part of the school work. In dealing with Indians I have learned from experience that it is comparatively easy to drift into a condition whereby Indians expect not only their education, medical care and relief allowances to be provided free, but also their clothing and even amusements, regardless of the opportunities that may arise from time to time for them to become self-supporting. This policy, in my judgment, invariably leads to the demoralization of the Indian population, just as our relief policy of a few years ago led to the demoralization of the white population. I feel confident, however, that as you gain in experience at the school you will be careful to safeguard against these dangers. It has occurred to me that you might use, very profitably and very effectively, in your vocational courses, a large amount of the

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, in which you ask for authority to spend the sum of $50.00 for the promotion of vocational instruction at the Maria School.

I may state that prior to the receipt of your letter I had informed the Principal of this school that she could spend an amount not exceeding $40.00. This information was conveyed to her in a letter dated September 26. If an additional amount of $10.00 is urgently needed, you are authorized to spend this amount. In view of the fact that we purchased a sewing machine, however, for this school it was our hope that $40.00 would be sufficient.

Would it be possible to have all requests for supplies, equipment, repairs, etc., in connection with the Maria School sent forward to the Department by you? This is the procedure followed at all other schools in the Dominion. The fact that we are in communication constantly with the Member of Parliament, the Principal of the school and the Indian Agent at Maria is very confusing and invariably leads to a great deal of unnecessary correspondence.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

During the month of September the Rev. Sister Mary of Lercie, the Principal of the Maria Indian Day School, informed the Department her intention to buy a Can Sealer to demonstrate to the pupils and the Indian ladies the advantage of the "canning"; she did not receive any definite answer from your Department if she was authorized to do this purchase.

After having taken informations from different Companies, the Principal of the School has located a good Can Sealer (the last one there was on the market) for a moderate cost, and she bought it.

This fall, many pupils, boys and girls, and many ladies of the Maria Reserve, went to the School at the request of the Principal, and they have shown a great interest by realizing the way it goes and the advantages given by a Can Sealer.

On my opinion, this purchase is justified and I am assured the Indians could take a great advantage of the demonstrations given to them. It is why, I would ask the Department to pay this account, because if this amount is taken from the $40.00 granted for the Manuel Training (girls) the balance will be not sufficient to cover the expenses for the whole year.

Hoping those explanations will be considered and that the Department will accept my demand. Thanking you in advance for your attention.

Yours very truly,

Edgar Arsenault, Farming Instructor,
Maria, Quebec.

To Mr. R. A. Hope,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa

Kind Mr. Hope:

I wish to thank you for all you have done for the Maria Indian Day School during the last term. All was appreciated both by teachers and pupils who are doing their very best to correspond to what is done for them.

Lately we had a distribution of about 157 pieces of their own made; they were dresses, boots, bonnets, scarfs, stockings, underwear and baby clothes. We have sent 5 or 6 pairs of games to the Military Officer in Quebec as requested by yourself.
Considering that the girls of the Junior class are not so in number, you will admit that they are very active.

Out of the unsewed and discarded there are remnants that are unusable unless woven for blankets etc., and there is the need of a house. Nothing is thrown away, everything, even the smallest shavings of material have been saved for the purpose.

A loan has been promised last year. I heard by M. Alp. Bonner M.P., one was coming, but we never got it. I think you will only be too glad to learn that we are wishing to undertake weaving work with our girls and probably some ladies would like it also.

Cooking is mentioned at the meeting tomorrow. I have provided a stove but a few pots, pans and tools would be required to give demonstrations of plain and economical cooking.

The Indians would certainly save much by not buying so many cans of preserved and ready food. Would you grant $20.00 for the purpose?
we would try and do with the most necessary articles although I know we can't get much for that amount; prices have been rising considerably.

A small ward-robe would be necessary to keep garments clean and in order as they are made until distribution day. $8.50 or $10 would be about the cost of such.

You probably don't know that no porch is attached to the school door and that 4 inches is the only space between it and the steps which lead to the classroom. The consequence is that the pupils coming in crowds, all shivered up, jam at the door, trying to shake off the snow and being obliged to keep the doors opened too long a time, the heat goes out and the cold comes in. Should a side building be attached to that side of the house it would serve both to the pupil's entrance and to a kitchen for the sisters. As it is now in the kitchenette the pump is exactly 20 inches from the left-hand, at the other end just the floor for the door to open. Sideways there are 6 feet.
between the table adjusted to the partition and the
girne. The reservoir being only 2 x 4 ft., the
sanitary has to pump several times a day,
and then the work is delayed in her work
being unable to take the necessary things
in the cupboard—pantry which is but one—
the "pump" filling up the space between
it and the pump.

All this is submitted to your kind attention
and we shall be grateful and satisfied for anything
you can do, remembering how kindly you have
treated us so far.

I have been trespassing on your kindness to
send such a long letter. All this was to be explained
verbally to Mr. Dorset as well as the elaboration
of a program for the vocational class, but to our
great disappointment, he did not visit us.

With respectful regards—

I remain,

Your humble servant,

Sister M. of Mercy, Prince

Edgar Greenaway

Maria, August the 19th, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Agricultural & Manual Training Courses.

The present is to ask the Department the authorization to begin my agricultural and Manual Training courses in the month of October. The reasons are the following:

During the month of September the majority of the oldest pupils are working at the digging of potatoes. And myself I will be busy to the supervision to put the potato seed in the Department cellar. It is my intention also to obtain the authorization for the erection of a root cellar for the Restigouche Reserve; the crop this year has a very good appearance in both reserves.

During the month of September, I have also to prepare the organization of the two fall fairs for Restigouche and Maria, and I ask at present the amount of $50.00 for Restigouche and $40.00 for Maria to cover the expenses and for the distribution of the prizes to the winners in each Reserve.

Last year the fair we have had a Restigouche, has been a very great encouragement for the Indians and they expect to have one again this year.

The Indians of Maria Reserve asked me to organize a fair this fall in their Reserve, and I am sure they would be very glad of it.

Last year they had only 14 gardens in the Reserve, and this year they have about 25, it is a good result.

At the end of September, about the 20th, I would like to take my regular holidays, because I have work to do for myself, and specially the hauling of my wood for winter time, and I expect the Department will accept to authorize them.

Hoping to receive soon your decision,

Edgar Arsenault, Arm. Inst.

Maria, Quebec.

Restigouche, June 5th, 1945

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Replying to your letter of June the 5th in connection with the amount of $24.10 to be paid to Sister Mary of Mercy, Principal of the Maria Indian School, I wish to inform the Department that according to your letter of April the 25th, I have met Mr. Cyr, and he has signed the account at the bottom to certify that payment was made.

This account has been forwarded to your Department with the voucher no:765,Maria, on May the 31st, and I hope it has reached the Department now.

As I have already forwarded this voucher with the signature of Mr. Cyr, as requested in your letter of April the 25th, I do not believe it is necessary to send another one, what would probably cause an other error for that same payment.

I do not want to put the blame on Sister of Mercy, I know she is far from the store and often she is obliged to give orders to somebody else to get what she needs for the sewing club. Consequently, very often the accounts are not prepared properly and I am obliged to look after it myself when I go down to Maria Reserve. It is one reason of the delay.

I wish to point out that since I have on hand the work for the Family Allowances, I can not do all my office work on time, and at present I have still many letters and reports not answered. As you know, there is no doctor on the reserve, and myself and my wife, we are delivering drugs day and night; owing that I have no constable since few months, there is always some Indians at the Office to complaint against others and we can not do any office work during they talk.

If the Department requires another voucher for that payment of $24.10 please inform me.

Edgar Arsenault, Agent.

Métiers à Tisser et Accessoires

Les métiers et accessoires "LECLERC" pour le tissage domestique et professionnel sont sur le marché depuis un grand nombre d'années, ils sont très bien connus pour leurs qualités supérieures.

Les Écoles, les églises, les écoles des gouvernements provinciaux, les Convents et Cercles de Femmes de tout le Canada utilisent les métiers à tisser "LECLERC". Ils sont robustes, solides et durables, très simples à manier, et donnent entière satisfaction. Partout ils sont connus, même en pays étranger.

Ils sont fabriqués en bois massif, parfaitement solides. Tous les joints sont faits à l'aide de mortier de chaux, qui est une substance naturellement dépourvue de toute qualité.

Construits pour le gros ouvrage aussi bien que pour le travail délicat, ils sont très résistants et les travaux les plus difficiles y sont exécutés, tels que la catalogue et le plus léger tissu peut être tissé avec facilité sur les métiers "LECLERC".

La pédale en forme ovale entraîne directement les cadres et a pour effet de répartir la résistance plus également sur les pédales.

Le frein nous permet de tendre la chaîne de manière précise et toujours uniforme sur la chaîne. Il se compose d'une tige de fer à vis, qui va d'avant à l'arrière du métier, tapissée par une roue de fer à vis, qui tourne autour du tambour arrière. Ce cercle de fer étant pressé sur le tambour, il donne à l'entraînement ainsi de trop dérouler, tout en permettant de rouler le tissu à volonté, sans avoir à retourner à l'arrière pour régler la chaîne, ce qui arrive lors qu'il n'y a pas de tissu.

Pour le montage de la pièce le tissu doit être desserré et ensuite serré au besoin pour maintenir les mailles.

Les métiers sont équipés de deux rouleaux, supportant les supports des rouleaux et les pédales, lesquels sont ajustés, prêts à être fixés aux métiers. Tous les autres accessoires sont expédiés séparément.

NOS PRIX SONT BAS PARCE QUE VOUS ACHETEZ DIRECTEMENT DE LA MANUFACTURE.

Weaving Looms and Accessories

"LECLERC" weaving looms and accessories are designed for domestic as well as professional work, having been favourably known for their high quality for many years.

Handicraft Guilds, Provincial Government Handicraft Schools and Missionary Women's Institutes all over Canada, as well as Missionary Schools abroad, use our weaving looms, because they are constructed of solid wood, perfectly sound. They are also known in foreign countries.

They are solidly constructed from highest grade yellow birch, all joints being tenoned and mortised and strongly bolted. All are finished in natural wood color, highly varnished.

Suitable for heavy as well as for light work, the looms are very strong and durable. Everything from heavy rugs to light cloth tissues can be woven with the greatest ease on a "LECLERC" loom. The peacock's tail shape treadle connects the pull on the harness and thus lightens the general operation of the loom.

The brake that we fix to the back beam permits us to control the tension on the warp. It consists of a screw bar running from the front to the rear which acts directly on a steel ring placed around the rear beam. This ring, when tightened on beam, takes up the slack when the cloth is advanced and stops the beam to spread out, but actually allows the cloth to be pulled out without the necessity of continually going around to the rear to adjust the warp, what happens when there is no tension.

In setting up the loom the brake is set slack and then tightened as the work progresses.

Looms are shipped assembled except for the two roller supports and pedals which are adjusted ready to be attached to looms. All other accessories are shipped ready to be put into operation.

Indian Day School, Maria
Dec 21, 1946

Dear Sir:
Please accept our sincere thanks for the courtesy extended to our request in furnishing the little house and the accessories required.

It will be all to the advantage to our Indian families, our little ones have the opportunity to learn weaving which will be very helpful to them.

Therefore, we beg you to grant us an amount of $25.00 to buy cotton and yarn necessary for weaving.

Owing to the increased price in raw material we are obliged to ask you another sum for our course in cooking. An item of twenty-five dollars yearly is not sufficient to get regularly every week, lessons in cooking although we always choose the most economical recipes.

In spite of your generosity, in the past, we are still lacking many kitchen utensils and the food supplies we had on hand are nearly all used up.
So we trust, kind Sir, you will realize the necessity of our situation and grant the two permits requested.

Thanking you in anticipation for your kind attention,

I beg to remain,

Your very respectfully,

Dr. W. J. St. Vincent

Principal

Bernard F. Carey
Superintendent of Welfare & Training
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa
Indian Affairs Branch,

I enclose herewith a letter received from the Principal of the Indian Day School, Maria Reserve, which is self-explanatory. I have realized during my different visit to the School that the pupil were very interested in cooking and knitting and that they were doing good work.

I therefore recommend an amount of $25.00 for the purchase of yarn and $25.00 to help the cooking class in order that they may continue their course.

Hoping it will be possible for the Dept. to approve my request.

(E. Arsenault)
Indian Agent.

Sir,

The month of June is over and I wish to give you an account in detail of my occupations as domestic instructor.

Deux ans après que je sois ici, je me suis occupée à veiller à la propreté des habitations d'abord en ordonnant une grande minage dans chaque maison, ensuite en faisant de fréquentes visites, particulièrement le samedi, afin de voir que tout soit à l'ordre pour le dimanche suivant.

Durant les heures de classe, profondément dévouée, j'enseigne aux dames sauvages à tailler le linge, à coudre, entretenir les maisons, à coudre, à passer le linge, les habits, à faire des pains à l'école, à partager les tas de... À l'école et quelques fois dans les familles, je leur montre encore la manière de blanchir le linge, de laver, de faire du savon, de cuire, de faire des pâtes, je donne à elles aussi conseils pour la cuisson de bois de chauffage, au four, prendre soin des ustensiles à leur usage. Plus que cela, je leur apprends à faire des petits travaux pour les empêcher de se divertir.

En somme je m'occupe à peu près de tout ce qui peut concerner les Indiennes qui, à l'égard, ne sont pas profit de ces instructions. C'est un grand service que je veille à la propreté "capable" qu'on ne peut négliger.

Madame Philomène Drolet.
For the two months I have resided here, I have attended to the direction of housekeeping among the Indians by ordering a thorough cleaning in every house, and followed this by frequent visits especially on Saturdays so that everything should be in good order for the following Sunday.

During the school hours properly, I teach the Indian women to cut clothes, sew, and how to keep the sewing machine in good order, to press clothes to iron, to mend, to knit, etc. At the school and sometimes at home I teach them how to bleach clothes and to dye them, also how to make soap and to bake bread. I also give them advice to provide for their firewood and how to care for the tools in their possession such as saws, chisels, axes, etc., so they would not deteriorate.

In short I do everything that may be useful to Indians who, I am sure, will profit thereby. Take special care that they keep their clothes clean.

Miss Philomena Drolet.

Sir,

Lately I received letters from the Indians at Maniwaki, Obedjiwan and Wemanotachee. They request to allow them to begin summer school the 15th of May instead of the first of June. They say:

1° That will help us to get away earlier to our hunting grounds, so that we will be able to hunt bears and also to buy and keep the whole harvest from coming on our land.

2° Early in spring, fish is more numerous around the school.

3° Our children will pick up berries earlier in fall.

To these motives, I will add: at the end of the summer all Indians are anxious to go back in the bush and always some families do not wait the closing of the classes.

If you give your approbation to their request, I will let it known as soon as possible, for the time is short.

T. R. L. MacJames
Secretary

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, the Department approves of the following appointments:

Salary at the rate of $80 per teaching month will be allowed to the teacher in charge and $65 per teaching month to the assistant teacher.

You should inform the above teachers of their appointment and arrange with them to commence duties on or about June first next. Each school may remain in operation until the end of September of this year.

At the end of each month, the teacher should prepare, on the usual form provided for that purpose, a statement showing attendance, days taught, etc. These returns should be forwarded to the Department in order that payment of the salary due can be made. Ottawa, May 31, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

Pursuant to your visit to the Department today, I am pleased to authorize you to proceed with the erection of a school building, with a second room for the assistant teacher's activity and a teacher's residence, at the Manawon Summer Indian Day School. It is understood that the Department's grant for this purpose will not exceed $720 and that there will be no teaching services this summer.

You should arrange to have receipted accounts, in duplicate, properly certified by yourself, presented to the Department in the fall. You will then be reimbursed to the amount of our grant. The Department would prefer receipts for materials rather than for labour or freighting. If, however, the materials do not cost $720, you should prepare a statement of the other expenses. It is hoped that the Indians will provide labour and that the buildings will be in readiness for the conduct of the school for the summer of 1928.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Your letter No. 69-1-5 dated Dec. 31, 1941.

Dear Sir,

Further to this question of building material, when in Sanmaur, Que., recently, Rev. E. Meilleur was requested to furnish me with information as to who authorized the purchase etc., of the material now charged to this Branch; nothing definite could be got by my own deductions were that, between the Manager of Hudson's Bay Company, the School Teachers and the Missionary, they decided to go ahead with this charge the Department hoping it will be approved.

For your immediate information, I informed at the time Rev. E. Meilleur, and a Teacher named Miss. Savard living now at Sanmaur, Que., positively nothing along these lines or others could be charged or paid for by the Department unless covered by an authority in advance from the Department. Under certain circumstances I informed them we might consider under "emergency" replacement of a broken glass, a broken padlock, or replacement of a stove pipe, but such replacements would have to be submitted together with letter of explanations, any other material required etc., must be submitted 1 year ahead of time for approval. In the future these persons should have no excuses to offer along that line.

I also communicated with Hudson's Bay Company to obtain a statement from their Manager at Manouan, who apparently assumed the task to put the bills through for payment. This Company was notified exactly as in the case of persons referred to in this letter.

Re: Iancuan Indian Reserve

When visiting this Reserve recently, the Indians drew attention to the fact that Rev. Ed. Meilleur had placed stakes north of teachers' house and that he claimed the ground as the property of the Mission; further this year there is a notice placed by Rev. Ed. Meilleur on the teachers' house stating that it is the property of the Mission.

I understand that the school teachers' house and the school buildings on any of these Reserves were put up at the expense of the Department, particularly at Iancuan the Mission done considerable repairs on the teachers' house, which may be their grounds to claim.

When at Weymontachie similar notices were put up by Rev. Ed. Meilleur, indicating that certain buildings are property of the Mission.

I feel the ownership of any buildings on these Reserves should be settled, particularly buildings not owned by Indians, also limits of lands if any under location tickets.

At Iancuan there is a notice put up, allowing trespass on Reserve, between sun-rise and sun-set signed by ORDER, this notice if not issued by order of the Department, I feel it should be removed please advise.

Mr. H. Lariviere, Supt. Indian Agency, Amos, P.Q.

We do not appear to have received any recent communication from you with reference to the erection of a school at Manouan. Do you propose to take out logs this winter so that the new school could be erected at this point in the summer of 1949?

If so, you should let me know the approximate expenditure that would be incurred previous to March 31, 1949 as we have some money in the current year's appropriation which we could use for the purpose on the understanding that all accounts would be submitted to the Department for payment before the date mentioned above.

Bernard N. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

PP/HM.
To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your No. 74-798 (E1) August 4th, 1948

In reply, nothing was done in connection with Manowan new school, we could easily get the necessary logs, ship in required lumber, gather other material for shipment when convenient during present fiscal year and complete in 1949.

For immediate I would appreciate authority as follows:

1.- Logs - work to be done by Indians at Manowan.

2.- Lumber - look around and secure from a local saw mill. This lumber we can store properly under cover at Manowan.

Above will cost about $1,200.00

3.- Material required, mainly windows, door, roofing paper, etc., gather and ship what we can before freeze up, make up balance and ship in winter.

Above will cost about $1,200.00

This would leave little material for 1949 and the labor to complete the building.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Ind. agency.

Manouan Indian Day School.

of logs, lumber, etc., required at this school.

Authority is given for you to have the
logs taken out by the Indians in the same way that

I am prepared to send you an accountable
advance of $2,000. to cover the labour costs in this
regard. If you prefer that this matter be handled

Unfortunately, I have absolutely no authority

by local purchase. As you know, all such requisitions
must be submitted to the Departmental Purchasing Agent
and he alone can give authority for local purchase.

I would, therefore, recommend that you send
in immediately requisitions covering the building materials
required and that these requisitions also include the
names of two or three firms whom you know are interested in
the supplying of these items.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Swaffield,

We may ship this fall, as early as possible, some building material for a new school set up on Manowan Reserve, whatever may go in, please store, like we did for Nursing Station supplies, needless to say the lumber will have been well piled, so it will dry, and won't warp.

As regard securing logs, I presume the Indians are in the working mood, we will want to get logs required cut this fall or during winter, for use immediately after break up next spring. As regard logs, when going to Manowan for ANNUAL VISIT, I will see Mr. Dery and arrange for Permit.

I cannot say exactly when I will be at Manowan, I expect anytime after September 10th., I will wire Mr. Dery a few days ahead, we are trying to complete Weymontachie on medical and from there move to Manowan.

Nurse Drouin will remain at Manowan, about 12 days, we want to check all Indians again on T.B. with "Patches" and vaccinate all those, that will stand up, this year it means only a few to be re-vaccinated with BCG and practically only the newly born on the Reserve. We are anxious to re-check all Indians.

Yours very truly,

H. Lariviere,
Supt. Indian Agency

Mr. A.B. Swaffield,
Manager, HBC Post,
Manowan via Casey, Que.

Retel desks for this school, we have no catalogue or informations as to models available; standard equipment recommended by the Division, in any event, considering they are not yet ordered, we could not handle this fall, to ship by air and take care, we have no mixed supplies to go in now before spring, the cost on air shipping considering weight would be out of all proportions, better leave this until spring 1949.

We will need desks, for Obedjiwan, Manowan and Weynontachie in 1949, together with Waswanipi order could be placed this late fall for spring delivery payalbe this year, delivery would be acceptable end of March 1949.

January 26th, 1949.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Att'n Mr. B. F. Neary, Supt. Education.

Further to our conversation when in Ottawa last, since I have prepared slowly to cover completion of Obedjiwan, Manowan and Mistassini schools.

Mr. Magnus Edwardson, who has been doing work for us on nursing stations and schools, is prepared to go in with others and do all this work this summer.

Considering, it is absolutely impossible to make arrangements for crews of men, their transportation, also supplies, at the last minutes; and to do these three jobs this summer it means rushing in immediately after break up and if possible before, that is last trips. I would appreciate authority to make arrangements to do this work on account season 1949-50.

As regard Waswanipi, it is only a matter of a man going in for about a month to complete details. Here, there is a plan underway to do some Indian houses, in any event some improvements. I estimate completion of the school will be possible probably through these other men, which means savings on transportation, etc.

Requisitions for supplies are being prepared now and I hope to be able to submit by early February for spring delivery if you have funds available on present fiscal year, or for early summer delivery as a charge to 1949-50 appropriations. Our summer program is developing to a new high, that is very heavy, and if we experience too many delays we won't be able to carry it out. Our medical service alone calls for 6 to 7 nurses in the field. Here as you know everything has to be worked out in full details to put it over. This with other things we have only 3 or 4 months to do it. Needless to say we must be prepared in advance and everything must be timed well ahead.

(Sgd) H. Lariviere, Supt.

August 8th, 1949

To the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Manowan School - New Buildings

Further to our recent telephonic conversation, new equipment for this Reserve is now going in, tractor, saw mill, etc., this should permit us to change from "log buildings" to "sawed timber". We have looked into the matter already and will endeavour to do all of these buildings in 4", which will allow a complete job, for permanent finish, interior and exterior.

Mr. Bondeau, Agency assistant, is going to supervise this work and other progress work.

I anticipate men from Obedji an will be able to move to Manowan before end of this month.

I spoke of this change from log to sawed timber to Mr. Doucet particularly and Mr. Gendron, with equipment on the Reserve we can do it to good advantage.

As regard 4" timber, Mr. Gendron suggested 3", since we have found out through the Colonization Department of Quebec, they are doing "settlers jobs" with 4" for they found it much better all around.

H. Lévesque - Supt. Indian Agency.
August 19th, 1949.

Mr. H. Lariviere,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Amos, P.Q.

Re: New School at Manawan, P.Q.

It is noted that now a saw mill is to be set up at Manawan, you intend to use sawed timbers rather than natural logs for this school.

I thought you would like to know that the Educational Survey Committee Members were satisfied with the log construction of the Obedjiwan and Mistassini Schools, their only suggestion being the addition of extra windows that you have agreed to carry out.

As Manawan is a more advanced community than the others, it is agreed that the school construction should be of a more advanced type, provided that the extra costs involved are reasonable.

It is noted that there are different opinions regarding the respective merits of three-inch and four-inch timber, and that you are following the example of the Quebec Colonization Department in using four-inch timber. It is assumed that this action conforms with the availability of local resources and with recognized conservation principles.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
August 26th, 1949.

Mr. H. Lariviere,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Amos, P.Q.

Re: New School at Manawan, P.Q.

With reference to your communication of the 9th instant and our reply of the 19th instant, I wish to add these further comments.

On Mr. Doucet's and Mr. Gendron's return, the matter of the kind of lumber to be used was discussed. From this discussion it is felt that a four-inch construction would be a great deal of waste. We would prefer that if at all possible, you should adopt the frame method of construction, i.e., 2 x 4's and sheeting. This will ensure you air space and will allow for insulation.

Your comments on this would be appreciated.

Bernard F. Neary,
AJDST
Supt. of Indian Education
Abitibi Indian Agency
Amos, Que.

August 26th, 1949

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: New School at Manowan, Que.

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Esq., Supt. Education
Your No. 319-5 (E3) August 10th, 1949

Yours came to hand, it is noted the Educational Survey Committee Members were satisfied with log construction in remote areas, the question of windows as discussed with them on the ground, since was adjusted. These jobs were first worked out on basis, our first conversation a few years ago, funds available, etc., cost and transportation.

As reg'rd Manowan, changes on equipment etc., transportation will be taken advantage of, this Reserve being more advanced, extra costs involved won't be much.

Allow to take advantage of this letter to report on:

Mistassini: This job will be completed early September, with extra windows, visited Mistassini about 10 days ago. Job very satisfactory.

Obedjiwan: This job completed a few days ago men being moved to Manowan Reserve, Obedjiwan has the full size windows, set-up, is exceptionally nice, location etc., water supply should stand up to best we have on our reserves, pump in residence, lack of material prevented us, running water into school. Indians clearing ground for fire protection, play yard and beach.

Attention: Mr. Doucet - teachers got real good work done by the boys, with tools, and the older girls made some very nice garments, clothing briefly being improved very much on this reserve, through our teachers.

At Mistassini, and Obedjiwan, certain minor details will be completed in 1950, could not hold crew waiting.

..........................
Through the number of delays experienced in spring, etc., I doubt we will be able to complete before freeze up; however we will endeavour to stay in there until freeze up.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian agency.
Abitibi Indian Agency
Amos, Que.

August 31st, 1949

To The Indian Affairs Department
Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. H. Lariviere

Your No. 319-5 (E.E.) August 26th, 1949

Re: Manawan New School: I have yours of the 26th. inst., in regard type of construction, if we could we certainly would do it in standard frame, 2 x 4, etc., however, it is a job in remote area, with all kinds of complications, mainly such as delays on getting out material, transportation inland, etc., the fact we have now a sawmill on the Reserve does not allow us, to go ahead and do frame construction yet, it will take us 2 years before we can do that.

We have experienced again certain delays since writing you, Assistant Boudreau, should be back here in a few days, and we will decide, on what we can do this fall etc., type of construction, etc., rest assured we will make a job of it, keeping in mind what we have done it with etc., costs, etc.,

As stated to you, if necessary we will only do the school this year, etc., I am an advance job on this Reserve, comparing with Obedjiwan etc., construction with us, is a difficult problem more so when almost everything does not stand up to "spring arrangement".

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian agent.

Sept. 24, 1949.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Ref: Manowan Indian Reserve

Further to sawmill, installed on this Reserve, I am pleased to report, that I have been informed through Mr. Boudreau, that sawing is going on up to expectations for this year and that logs for school are being sawed to take care, carpenters on school job making satisfactory progress, with help of tractor etc., things are moving faster.

Briefly, as a whole, in spite of many delays, by freeze up work will be advanced.

Through sawmill, lumber was done for flooring and roofing our Implement Shed. This is now completed, so all equipment will be well stored. The sawmill is being also covered for operations during bad weather and protection.

I understand the Indians caused certain difficulties. They all wanted to stick close to Mill when in operations and so on. They more or less disputed the slabs. Very likely the spectators if asked to work, with time will disappear for immediate they all give a hand.

Indians, the few employed, are being trained to do various jobs. We hope next Spring our local "crew" will be of real use.

(Sgd.) H. Lariviere
Supt. Indian Agency.
Ottawa, October 8, 1949.

H. Lariviere, Esq.,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Amos, Que.

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter dated September 24th, file 7-4-8, and I wish to congratulate you on the progress that is being made in the sawing of lumber on the Manawan Indian Reserve.

It is noted that logs are being sawed for the construction of a school, and inasmuch as the cost of operating the Mill is being met from Welfare Appropriation it will be necessary for you to submit a voucher or vouchers covering the cost of production of this lumber. In this way your Housing Appropriation, against which the original cost of producing the lumber is charged, is credited and the Education Division Appropriation is debited by the same amount.

November 8th, 1949

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: School Buildings

Refer your letter No. 319-5 dated November 2, 1949

As regard providing for season 1950/1951, on our Estimates, we estimated as follows:

a) $4,695.00 - for various equipment, etc.,

b) $1,800.00 - for general repairs, to certain buildings,

c) $19,400.00 - for completing various projects and covering mentioned possibilities during visit of Educational Survey.

When estimates were prepared, we were not sufficiently advanced on various projects, to establish definitely what would be left for following season; however at this time, it appears it covers fairly well.

H. Lapiviere - Supt. Indian Agency.
To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Manowan Indian Day School
Your No. 319-5 (E) November 2, 1949

The buildings at Manowan on closing job, stood as follows:

1. School - To complete exterior - interior covered.
2. Residence - To complete exterior - interior covered - temporary - fully protected.
3. Storage - Walls up.

Owing to the fact it was possible to change type of construction from logs to sawed timber, not possible to make a frame standard job, it was done in 4 x 4", except storage, rough lumber. At this time I do not know yet, what is our total cost against these buildings, however we are clearing now all charges and we hope by late December to establish our cost, order material to complete, so it will leave us if possible only labor for season 1950/51, and small sundry items.

This job, to complete requires, installing water system, my views on it are, regular well, with pressure tank unit and motor, to supply residence and school, sewerage is an easy matter to take care at Manowan. As regard finishing floors, I feel a permanent job should be made, we could use Asphalt Floor Tile, this would save painting and allow long life, easy upkeep and overcome the flooring covering problem, annual painting, exterior a finish with Insul Brick 2" would be very suitable and as cheap as lumber overcome the painting end of it, interior Wallboard or equal painted (walls and ceilings) I would appreciate hearing from you.

As regard proposed new class room, as discussed with the Educational Committee, same size as present school (new) we provided site, we could do this job with greater ease in 1950, here a full size basement, to take care of woodwork training, etc.,...........

Re: Manouan Indian Day School

In connection with this school, we find that expenditures from April 1st, 1949, to January 1st, 1950, amount to $6,436.00. We provided in our appropriation an amount of $6,500.00. The balance in the appropriation, namely $64.00, is not sufficient to meet the following Vouchers which you have recently forwarded:

Voucher #1054 - $319.78
#1064 - $475.64

Total - $795.42

It is understood that you have now submitted Vouchers for all the expenditures that will be incurred for the construction of this school during the current fiscal year.

We will have to arrange a transfer of funds from some other project, and this will involve two or three weeks time, and therefore, Vouchers #1054 and #1064 cannot be paid until the transfer is effected.

As shown above, the total expenditures on this building to date are $7,231.42 ($6,436.00 plus $795.42). We have also received your requisition of December 1st requesting additional material at an estimated cost of $530.56, to which will be added the cost of shipping.
The situation at the present time, therefore, is as follows:

Expenditures, fiscal year 1949-50 - $7,231.42
Additional material - $530.56
Shipping charges on materials (estimated) - $300.00

Total - $8,061.98

We would like you to advise us of the additional amount that will be required for wages to complete the building. We would also like to know if any additional materials will be required.

In view of the expenditures already incurred, and the additional amount that will be necessary, it would appear that the cost of this building will be in the neighbourhood of $10,000.00. As stated in the case of the Mistassini School, we feel that the expenditure has been very high, and we would appreciate having an explanation of the whole matter.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
