OTTAWA 19th February 1897

MEMORANDUM relative to a second school on the Maniwaki Reserve

In reference to an application lately received from Miss K.O'Connor for the position of teacher on the Maniwaki Reserve, should a second school be opened there,

The undersigned begs to state that the number of children of school age on the Reserve is 75, while not more than 30 can attend the school now in operation, which is situated on Desert River, about a mile and a half west of the Village of Maniwaki. There is quite an Indian settlement south of the Village along the Gatineau Road, the children of which have no opportunity to attend school.

The question of moving the present school to more central locality has been proposed, but it has been shown that there is not site on the Reserve where a school could be placed to accommodate all the children. The north eastern settlers could more easily reach the Gatineau Road than any other locality.

The undersigned is of opinion that if an additional amount of say $150 per annum could be provided, it would be possible to carry on two schools. The Band now contributes $300.
$300 for salary and pays all other charges in connection with the school, while not more than 30% of the children are benefited by this expenditure.

Sgd Martin Benson

Information for Purchasers of Canada's War Savings Certificates

Date of Issue. War Savings Certificates will be dated the fifteenth of the month in which payment is completed. For example, whenever in any one month your Total Saving Deposits are sufficient to buy your War Savings Certificate, that Certificate will bear the date of the 15th of that month.

Registration. Each War Savings Certificate is registered at the Bank of Canada, Ottawa. Registration will be made by serial number only. A War Savings Certificate is not transferable and cannot be redeemed other than by its registered owner. Provision has been made for redemption in case of the death of a holder.

Care should be taken to state clearly the name and address in which each deposit Certificate is registered. Spell out the first or Christian name in full, as well as the surname, and give proper prefix (Mr., Mrs., or Miss).

For example: Correct — BROWN, MR. KENNETH D.
Incorrect — Ken Brown.
A married woman should furnish her own Christian name (not that of her husband).
For example: Correct — WHITE, MRS. MARGARET F.
Incorrect — Mrs. H.

Purchase Limits. No person may hold War Savings Certificates in excess of a total maturity value of $500 purchased in any one calendar year. That is to say, you may purchase $500 worth this year, and up to a like amount in each succeeding year.

Income Tax. Due to the difficulties of calculation, the small amounts involved and the limit on individual holdings, holders will not be required to report the difference between the purchase price and the redemption value of War Savings Certificates as income in making returns under the Income War Tax Act.

Redemption. War Savings Certificates cannot be called for redemption by the Government prior to their date of maturity. The holder, however, has the option six months after issue date of redeeming the certificates for cash, and after the first year will also be paid interest to the date of redemption in accordance with the current redemption values shown on each certificate. The Minister of Finance reserves the right to require ninety days' notice in the case of redemption before maturity.

RE: Schools on Maniwaki Indian Reserve.

Herein please find a report on both the Maniwaki Indian Schools for the month of September 1945.

Maniwaki Indian Day School: At this School the attendance is altogether too large for one teacher. There is there at the moment 56 Indians going to School and 6 white pupils. It is a fact that something would have to be done and out of these whites there are four partly Indian kids and two purely white. There is no doubt that it would be quite hard to send away the Indian blood Indians considered to be white. We could though advise the white pupils (2) that they would have to go to the Village School. This to my knowledge would not relieve the situation as 60 children is yet too big a class for one teacher, especially when she has to teach all of the grades. I consider that if they were all in the same grade, that class would not be too numerous, providing it would be in the lower grades.

The fact that this School is overcrowded and no place to move, dirties the class-room a lot more and although the Janitor, who at the moment is the Chief, has been warned to keep the School clean, it is far from being clean and the Teacher has too much work to look after everything. I am not blaming the Teacher so much as the lack of organization in this School. In the first place the water has to be drawn for nearly 10 acres and that is the most important thing in a School. The washing facilities are therefore very limited and the laziness to the Janitor makes it worst. There is also the question of the
salary of a Janitor at this School. Last year for part of the year the Janitor was getting $10.00 a month, the Department increased it during the year to $15.00 a month. I claim that this is still too low. The Department should pay a Janitor enough to make it interesting for him, and if he does not do the work properly, we could easily get another one. The way it is there, at that price, we cannot get a Janitor that will do the work, leaving this extra work to the Teacher.

In summing up the whole situation it is very easy to see that is something is not done about this school, the Department cannot expect very much success and they are spending good money for hardly any results.

Gongo Bridge Indian Day School: This School is sufficiently big enough for the attendance but I am in doubt whether or not the Teacher there shall make a success of it. The School is far from being as tidy as it was, and to my estimation the Teacher is a little lacking in neatness. As far as the teaching abilities of the teacher, I cannot say very much, but this shall be judged by the success she will attain later on.

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Quebec.

I have your letter of July the 18, 1946, concerning certain suggestions that have been made to the Department of Indian Affairs, concerning improvement of the educational services of the Maniwaki Agency:

(a) Bitobig - A new school should be built there. It is a fact that something should be done for the children living on the Bitobig road in regard to education. Nevertheless it is hard to decide whether or not a new School should be built on that road or another arrangement organized to take those children to the Maniwaki Indian Day School, if it is to be enlarged. The difficulty in all of those Schools on this Indian Reserve is that the teachers cannot get living accommodations on the Reserve and they have to walk from Maniwaki Village to the School, which would give them approximately six miles. The same situation develops at the Congo Bridge Indian Day School and it is why we are now asking to have living quarters for the Teacher built at that School. Personally I have always been of the opinion that a main School as much as possible should be built for the Reserve, where almost all of the children could attend, by taking them to School with a Busk or an organization of some kind. By having one School for all the children of the Reserve, you could have three teachers who would divide amongst them the children of the nine grades we have on the Reserve. Another fact is that by having one School you could have a principal who would look after
this main School and also supervise the other teachers under him. I have absolutely no confidence in those small Country Schools where generally a young girl has to teach from the first to the ninth grade and where there is hardly any supervision over her.

Naturally the Department has the final say in these decisions and if you judge that no main school should be built to take all of the children of this Reserve and small schools would be better, I am of the opinion that you need one on the Bitobig road, as there is at least 22 children on that road who do not go to School because they are living too far away.

(b) Congo Bridge School should be enlarged. My same argument as for the previous school mentioned in this letter is my opinion, nevertheless I do not believe you shall obtain any success whatever with those small schools here and there. Again if you decide that this is not the Department's opinion it would almost be necessary to build living quarters for the Teacher at that School as there is no living accommodations on the Reserve, around that School and the teacher has to walk from 5 to 6 miles to go and teach every morning.

(c) School on the Public Road should have two teachers instead of one. At that School at the moment there is too many pupils attending for one teacher and as there is no other place in the building for another class I do not see any other way if you want to have another teacher there, is to enlarge the school. Naturally my previous suggestion should be studied very carefully and I am of the opinion that instead of spending money on another class for this School, would be to build big enough to have three classes, which would take care of all the children on the Indian Reserve and have living accommodations at least for the Principal of that School. As this school is situated
about one mile from the Maniwaki Village the other teachers could easily live in the Village and go to their work every morning. At the moment there is no one living there, the Teacher lives in Maniwaki and this year this school has been broken in three times and I was there this morning and discovered that it still has been broken in since the holidays and six windows are completely broken, that would need to be repaired immediately. One thing that should be done at that School immediately is get an Artesian well dug immediately. There is no water at that School and it has to be drawn about 10 acres. We have in Maniwaki a contractor who digs wells and I am sure he would be glad to dig one for the Department at that School so a pump could be installed and later on also install electric lights and a pressure pump who would give you sufficient water for drinking, for the residence and for all of the toilets that could easily be installed in the cellar, after a cesspool has been built outside the building. You will find that in my estimates of this year I included these works for this particular School but nothing was included for building a new class at that particular School. I would suggest a survey of the situation be made by one of the Department's employees and a report be made to the Department in regard to the suggestions I have made in this letter.

I may add in closing that since I have been Indian Agent of this Reserve, no ameliorations has been noticed in regard to education. It is the most important factor and the only one that the Department will succeed in making anything out of those Indians on this Reserve. If nothing is done in this regard, the Indians instead of improving their situation, are going backward.

J.E. Gendron, I.A.

Mr. J. GRENDON, Indian Agent. Complaint of re: B.E. & Theft of Indian Day School.

1. The writer while on patrol at Maniwaki, P.Q., per. P.C. 3646, accompanied by Cst. Duns, received a complaint from Mr. Joe GRENDON regarding a B.E. & Theft of the above noted school.

2. Mr. GRENDON informed the writer that during the early part of the summer school holidays six of the school windows had been broken and the school entered. Upon commencement of school, the Teacher Miss Marie BRENNAN reported the theft of a silver tray, 6 dinner plates, 1 cup, and 6 water glasses. The tray was silver in appearance only, and not handles, there was an engraved design in the center. The plates and cup belonged to a set, and had a green floral design of dark green around the edges. Miss BRENNAN stated that she could easily identify the stolen articles, if recovered.

3. Numerous persons, both school children and adults were questioned regarding this theft, but nothing of value was learned that would assist in bringing this case to a successful conclusion. Several houses were entered during the course of the above patrol, but none of the above articles were noted by members of the patrol. Neither the Indian Agent nor the School Teacher had any suspects in mind nor any suggestions to make.

4. Further enquiries will be made when next in Maniwaki and a further report will be submitted to comply with the undermentioned Diary Date.

With reference to the above, and further to previous report, when on patrol in the Maniwaki Distr. during the latter part of December 1946, the following enquiries were made, with negative results.

Chief TISSOT, Mr. GENIERON, and the school teacher Miss BRENNAN were again interviewed regarding the above, but could offer no suggestions or new information that would assist in this enquiry.

The matter of DENOMIE having lived opposite the school during the B.E. & Theft was discussed with Chief TISSOT and he was of the opinion that the subject had not resided there at the time of the theft, therefore could hardly be responsible. He stated that it was the consensus of opinion amongst the Indians, that this offence had been committed by some of the younger Indian lads, who undoubtedly destroyed the loot or cashed it in the bush.

Some of the older Indians were questioned regarding this opinion, and when questioned as to what grounds this opinion was based upon stated that they believed that this was a retaliation or revenge for having been convicted on a previous charge of breaking into this school. The lads responsible for the previous trouble at the school were not on the Reservation at the time the patrol was in the vicinity these men will be interviewed at the first opportunity, and their homes searched in an endeavour to locate the missing kitchen ware taken from the school.

No one in authority at the school have any idea as to when the school was broken into, other than that it took place sometime during the school holidays (two months) and have no information, nor suggestions that would assist with the enquiry, however it is hoped that information of value can be secured when in the Maniwaki Distr. on the next patrol.

Maniawaki Indian Day School:

This school is a very good building which was improved considerably during the past year.

Attendance is very good. The teacher is very devoted and is quite successful. Good housekeeping should be taught and would strongly recommend that hot soups and drinks be given regularly to those pupils having lunch at school. This would be prepared by the older girls under the teacher's supervision and direction. This would be one efficient means of training for those girls.

A Junior Homemaker's Club should also be organized and the teacher should give such an organization much attention. Competitions in handicraft should be encouraged.

A small open air skating rink could be provided at a very low cost. Upkeep of which would be done exclusively by the pupils.

If this school was under the direction of a religious order such as the Grey Nuns, I am sure would be a step forward in the right direction. This possibility should be kept in mind and taken advantage of at first opportunity.

Sir,

Owing to unforeseen circumstances I was obliged to put a qualified teacher in my place in the Maniwaki Indian School on Feb 16th 1927 intending to resume my duties in a few days. However it would inconvenience me very much to return and would like if the Department would permit me to have a teacher replace me until the end of my term on Feb 28th 1927. Please let me know if this meets with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,
Margaret McCaffrey.
Ottawa, February 23rd, 1927.

Madam:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, in which you advise that you found it necessary to arrange for a substitute teacher at the Maniwaki Indian Day School from the 7th instant. In reply I beg to say that, at the end of the present month, a cheque for your salary for January and February will be issued and sent to you. When you receive this, you should arrange for the payment of the substitute teacher from February 7th to the 28th.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss M. McCaffrey,
Maniwaki,
Que.
Ottawa, February 22nd, 1927.

Sir,

I have your No. 2 of the 17th instant, suggesting the temporary appointment of Miss Florence McAuley at the Maniwaki Indian Day School, at a salary of $37.50 per teaching month. Your recommendation is approved, and you will please inform Miss McAuley of her appointment as from March 1st. It is understood that the position will be considered vacant as from June 30th, next, and the best available teacher will be engaged for September 1st.

Miss McCaffrey, who is leaving our work, asks permission to engage a substitute for a portion of the current month. Approval has been granted, and I have asked her to sign the return, which should be forwarded to the Department on the 28th instant. Miss McCaffrey will then arrange to pay the substitute.

I request that you give my letter of the 19th instant careful consideration and make a recommendation concerning Miss Margaret Lynch and Miss Lizzie McGregor. There is no reason why a permanent appointment as from September 1st cannot be made at this time.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Que.
Ottawa, February 26, 1927.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, furnishing particulars as to the qualifications of Miss Lizzie McGregor, whom you recommend for the position as teacher of the Maniwaki Indian Day School for the school year beginning on or about September 1st, 1927.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss McGregor, to begin duties on the date mentioned. Her appointment to be for a year's trial only, and her retention in the position after that time to depend entirely upon the success which she achieves in her work. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $60 per teaching month. Please inform her of her appointment, and arrange in due time that she will be ready to commence duties when the school reopens after the summer holidays, next. I shall be pleased to hear from you as to whether she accepts the position. You should give her every assistance you can when she takes up duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Que.

MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury.

Re:- School No. 320.

Owing to illness, Miss Carmel McGuire, the regular teacher at the Maniwaki Indian Day School, was unable to resume duties on September 1st and she was allowed one month's leave with pay.

In order to keep the school open, her sister, Miss Mae McGuire, was engaged as substitute teacher at the same salary for the month of September. As Miss Carmel McGuire was unable to resume duties at the end of September, Miss Mae McGuire has continued in charge of the school until the end of December. She is, therefore, entitled to pay for four months, viz., September $60 - October $80 - November $80 and December $80, or $320. Miss Carmel McGuire, the regular teacher, has not been allowed any salary since the end of September.

Memorandum:

Re: Maniawki Indian Day School,

EXTRACT from Report of Mr. Inspector Maltais, dated March 11th, 1931, on his inspection of the MANIWAKI INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on File 18-2-6.

The walls of the classroom are badly cracked in some places. They will need repairs in the near future.

It is evident that the kind of stove used in the classroom takes too much space, being placed in the middle of the classroom. With the new kind of stove which can be placed in the corner of the classroom, it would give more room for the pupils. At present, one-third of the classroom cannot be used on account of that stove.

At least five desks ought to be replaced. They are not only in bad shape, but might be a danger for the pupils.

Some of the school desks are not proportionate to the age of the pupils; something could be done along that line.
Ottawa, March 26, 1931.

Sir:

The Provincial School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Maniwaki Indian Day School, states that the walls of the classroom are badly cracked in some places, requiring repairs in the near future. He also states that the stove in use in the classroom takes up too much space and that, if a new stove, of a type which can be placed in a corner of the room, was installed, it would give more space for the pupils. He further states that at least five desks ought to be replaced.

You might furnish your opinion regarding the repairs required to the walls of the classroom and state whether you would recommend that a new stove be installed. You should give an estimate of the cost of carrying out any recommendations made by you.

Regarding the new desks, please state whether those at present in use are single or double, and, if you have the information, the name of the manufacturer. This may be stamped on the metal part of the desks. The size and the number of each size of new desks required should be stated.

When we have the information asked for, consideration will be given as to whether the equipment mentioned can be provided and the work of repairing the classroom carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent
MANIWAKI, P. Q.
Ottawa, March 12th, 1931.

Sir:

As instructed I visited the Maniwaki reserve in connection with certain complaints made to the Department by Mrs. James Brascoupe, a white woman married overseas to an Indian soldier, and the leader of a faction known as the "Rebels" and who are opposed to everything and everyone connected with the Department.

The interior of the school is in very bad state of repair. The plaster is cracked and while perhaps not dangerous, is most unsightly and neglected looking. If funds are available this summer, I would recommend that the walls and ceiling of both the classroom and entrance porch be plastered or beaverboarded and painted. The outside of the building is in fair condition. I could not see the condition of the roof as it was covered with snow. This should be determined before anything is done to the interior.

Your obedient servant,

Thos. McGookin.
Inspector.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

June 24, 1931.

Memorandum: Mr. Carrier.

While at Maniwaki last week I was asked by Indian Agent Gauthier to make an inspection of the day school building, where some repairs were to be authorized. The above mentioned building is 17 x 25 feet - one story, consisting of an entirely wooden structure. The repairs which I consider necessary are as follows:

1. Covering of the plaster walls with a layer of beaver board.
2. Painting of the wooden ceiling and dado.
3. Erection of three wooden steps at the entrance which are entirely demolished.
4. Putting of a layer of earth around the foundation to prevent cold coming through the classroom floors.
5. Repairing of the chimney which is partly demolished.

With reference to the desks in the building there are -

6 desks No 2, 29" high.
1 desk No 3, 27" high.
6 desks No 4, 26" high.

These desks have no manufacturers' names on them. Three of them are broken and should be repaired.

If the present stove, which is installed in the centre of the classroom be moved or replaced by a new one installed in one of the corners of the classroom there would be room for six additional desks.

The total cost of the above mentioned work exclusive of the desks and stove would be about $125.00.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Perrier.

Re: Maniwaki Indian Day School.

I visited this school recently. Twenty-six pupils were present. Number on roll is Thirty. The teacher states that she has quite often as high as 36 in attendance. In my opinion the school is too small. The class room is 17x23, poorly ventilated. The pupils are crowded too close together in double seats. Only five new single seats.

Additional blackboard space is needed. The blackboards in use are badly worn and scratched and should be replaced. The following would meet the needs:

- 2 pieces for side walls, length - 8'6"
- 2 pieces to replace old ones, length - 6'6"

The closets are in very bad state of repair, dirty and unsuitable. Only one closet is in use for all pupils. The other one is closed by stove-ends piled against the door. The location is not good. I would recommend that two new closets be built and placed at the rear boundary of the school lot. The present ones are past repairing.

[Signature]

INSPECTOR.
Ottawa, December 4, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Maniwaki Indian Day School, draws attention to the need of additional blackboard space and also recommends that two new closets be built.

An order is being sent to the Government Stationery Office to forward addressed to you two pieces asbestosolate blackboard for the side walls and two pieces to replace old ones at present in use. You should arrange to accept delivery when this material arrives and have it installed in the classroom.

Regarding the erection of two new closets, I have to request that you will inform the Department as soon as possible of the approximate cost of the material and labour required in erecting these buildings. It is not intended that an expensive type be erected, but, if authorized, a good substantial job should be completed. Mr. McGookin states that the location of the present toilets is not good and that new toilets should be placed at the rear boundary of the school lot. When we have full information as to the cost involved in the erection of new closets, you will be further advised as to whether they can be authorized at the present time or not.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Maniwaki Indian Day School

Inspector McGookin visited this school on April 11th and reports that there are 38 children on the roll. There is seating accommodation in the school for 32 pupils and there were 31 pupils present on the day of his visit. The teacher told him that there are seven more children who wish to attend after the Easter holidays.

Mr. McGookin states that the room is crowded at present, and, consequently, there is no room for additional desks.

When funds are available, Mr. McGookin recommends the erection of a new combined school and teacher's residence.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Chene,

Mr. Buskard telephoned me this morning to say that some people from Maniwaki were at the minister's office and complained about the condition of the school building and the roads and bridges on the reserve.

It was suggested that you be sent to investigate the matter and report but Mr. Buskard would like to see you before you go.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Chene,

Mr. Buskard telephoned me this morning to say that some people from Maniwaki were at the Minister's office and complained about the condition of the school building and the roads and bridges on the reserve.

It was suggested that you be sent to investigate the matter and report but Mr. Buskard would like to see you before you go.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
SCHOOL.

The School building in question is the Maniwaki School, located on the Hull Maniwaki Provincial Highway (Route No II). This building consists of an entirely wooden structure, 17 x 25 feet, one story.

I found it to be in a very poor condition, and much too small to accommodate the pupils attending it, as mentioned in Inspector McGeekin's report of December 1, 1931.

I was advised while at the school that at least 12 pupils were refused admission last year on account of the existing crowded conditions.

The woodshed, located near the school, offers an ugly sight, and is partly demolished. The whole building should be either reconstructed or repaired.

The School lot also is in a very bad condition. Large boulders are scattered all over and protrude above the ground. The ground itself is full of holes and large depressions making it dangerous as a playground for children.

In view of the above mentioned facts and on account of this school being located in full view of one important provincial highway, I would recommend that a new building of the required dimensions to accommodate about 50 pupils be erected and provided with Department standard equipment for a school of this type. I estimate that the cost of such a building would be between $4,000 and $7,500 under ordinary conditions.

It is possible that some of the materials from the present building could be used in the construction of a new school, and in the building of the woodshed.

The question of erecting a combined day school and teacher's residence is well worth considering on account of the distance between the school and the town of Maniwaki, in case the teacher should be compelled to live in the town.

Departmental Engineer.
ROADS.

The roads on the Maniwaki Reserve are generally in a fairly good condition, with the exception of the Desert Road. The construction of this road was started last year when an amount of $1,000 was expended from band funds for the improvement of this road which was an old wagon road with a very narrow driveway, without any form of grading or drainage. The Desert road is about 9 miles long, entirely within the boundary of the reserve. It is mostly used for the transportation of pulpwood purchased from the Maniwaki Indians. It was the intention to gradually improve it in order that it might be used throughout the year for the above mentioned purpose by expending a certain amount annually either from band funds or Parliamentary appropriation.

There is no special item in this year's Estimates for road work of any kind on the Maniwaki Reserve, and in order that the portion of the road which was partly improved last year might be kept in a state of repair, I would suggest that $500 be taken from the amount of $2,000 provided for the bridge, referred to under the heading "Bridges" to pay for this maintenance work and the construction of an additional piece of road if possible. This would give employment to a number of Indians for a time, which would be appreciated owing to their needy condition.

The work, if authorized, would be performed under the supervision of Indian Agent Gauthier, with the assistance of an Indian foreman, as has been done in the past.

Should it not be possible to complete the bridge in question with the remaining balance of $1,500, which I believe is quite sufficient, the necessary additional funds could be provided in next year's Estimates.

I might add that it is probable that the Indians will consent, before the end of the season, to expend some of their band funds for the completion of a section of this road, as was done last year.
BRIDGES.

The bridges on the Maniwaki Reserve are in good passable condition.

There is however a new bridge required over a Creek or Gully on the Gatineau Road on lot 25 or 26, for which an amount of $2,000 has been provided in this year's Estimates.

This new bridge will consist entirely of a timber structure and the work should be carried out by day labour, most of which should be performed by white carpenters under the supervision of a white foreman. Indians, of course, would be employed for unskilled labour such as the construction of the approaches, or as helpers to the carpenters.

As funds are available, and weather conditions favourable, I would recommend that this work be authorized and that I be advised of the name of the foreman to be employed, also the names of white carpenters.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Buskard,

Referring to the second paragraph of your memorandum of the 17th instant, regarding the erection of a new school building on the Maniwaki Reserve, I have to say that there were no funds specially provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year.

There is, however, an item to the amount of $6,000 for the erection of a two-roomed school building on the White Bear's Reserve, No. 70, Moose Mountain Agency, Sask. The Indians are about equally divided between the United Church and Roman Catholic Church denominations. There have been protests received from the Church officials of both these denominations against a combined school for the Catholic and Protestant children. In discussing the matter with Dr. McGill, it was considered that, in view of further protests that would likely arise in the erection of this school, the building should not be proceeded with at the present time.

Should the building on the White Bear's Reserve not be proceeded with, the amount provided could be utilized in the erection of the school building on the Maniwaki Reserve.

I would suggest that this is a matter for the Minister's decision as to whether he prefers that the amount required - approximately $5,000 - be utilized in the erection of a school building on the Maniwaki Reserve, to provide accommodation for approximately 40 children, rather than proceeding with the work of erecting a school on the White Bear's Reserve.

Memorandum:

The Honourable the Superintendent General

With reference to the new combined day school and teacher's residence now under construction of the Maniwaki Indian Reserve, Que., I beg to give you the following information:

Upon instructions received from the Minister's office on July 11th, the Engineer of the Department proceeded to Maniwaki or or about the 15th of July to make an inspection of the old Maniwaki Day School. He reported that the building was in a poor condition, too small to accommodate the pupils attending it, and recommended that a new school be provided.

As no funds had been especially provided for the erection of this school, it was decided to use the funds that had been included in the Estimates for the erection of a two room school building on the White Bear's Indian Reserve No 70, Moose Mountain Agency, Sask., which was postponed until a later date.

Plans were accordingly prepared and the work commenced by day labour on September 15th, under the supervision of Mr. Edmond Dupras, of Gracefield, Que. Owing to an accident which occurred shortly after the work started Mr. Dupras was incapacitated, and Mr. Henri Leduc was employed as foreman, and the work has since then been carried out under his supervision.

The estimated cost of the work was $6,500.00 and to date the building is partly sheeted in and is now being shingled.

Deputy Superintendent General.

October 31, 1935.

Memorandum: Doctor McGill.

Re: New combined Day School and Teacher's Residence at Maniwaki, Que.

As per instructions I made yesterday another inspection of the above mentioned building, and beg to give you the following information.

The ground around the building has been cleared of trees and brush, which were considered a nuisance and a danger, these being taken away where it is expected that they will be cut into fuel wood.

The concrete foundation of the building is entirely completed as well as the framing, including the stained shingle roof, with the exception of the porches and verandahs.

The exterior of the building is now ready to receive the clapboard sheeting and cornices.

Part of the inside board sheeting is also completed ready to receive the gyprock sheeting, and the window frames are ready for adjustment in place.

The brick chimney is completed.

A drain made of 4 inch tile has been laid from the basement as far as a gully located quite a distance from the building to ensure the drainage of the basement and which can be used for the disposal of sewage should a bathroom be installed in the teacher's residence, which installation is now being recommended in a separate memorandum to the Schools Branch.

The basement floor is ready to receive the cement finishing coat.

The above mentioned work, with the exception of the clearing and levelling, was mostly performed by white labour in a thoroughly satisfactory manner.
The work has progressed in a surprisingly quick manner, considering the difficulties which were encountered in the excavation for the basement, which was done in solid granite, requiring much labour and time, and consequently heavy additional and unforeseen expenses.

The work up to the present has cost approximately $2,900 for labour, and $2,200 for materials already supplied but not paid for, which means that a total expenditure of $5,100 has been made to date.

I estimate that under the same arrangements the work could be completed for approximately $3,500.

I beg to advise that the difference between the estimated cost of $6,500 and that now estimated is due to the fact that part of the school lot had to be cleared, and levelled, a drain had to be constructed to ensure the drainage of the basement, etc., and the extra excavation which had to be done in solid granite.

It is understood that Indian Agent Gauthier, who had charge of the purchasing of the materials up to the present time, will send all accounts, pay-lists, etc. to the Department within the course of a day or so.

Departmental Engineer.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

October 31, 1955.

Memorandum: Doctor McGill.

It would be advisable that arrangements be made at the earliest possible date for the removal of the old school at Maniwaki some distance away from the new building.

I understand that the Indians would like to secure this school to be used as a Council House.

As you know they would be unable to attend to such work and I doubt if removal could be successfully made on account of the dilapidated condition of the wooden sills, etc.

In any event I presume that the expenditure would have to be charged to the funds of the band. I would therefore suggest that prices be obtained for the removal of the building to a site across the highway, and that the matter be submitted to the Indian Council for their decision as to whether they would be prepared to bear the expenditure.

Otherwise, I would recommend that the Indians be allowed to demolish it and rebuild it under the direction of a competent foreman.

Departmental Engineer.
I understand that an artesian well is authorized to provide safe drinking water for the above mentioned building. Will you please advise if provision should be made at the present time for the installation of a small bathroom adjoining the bedroom on the first floor of the building, at a cost of about $175.00.

As mentioned in a separate report to the Deputy Minister as to the progress of the work, a four inch drain has been laid from the basement of the building to a gully some distance from the school which could be advantageously used for the disposal of sewage from the bathroom and kitchen.

If this is to be authorized, I would like to be advised as soon as possible.

Before the excavation work was commenced for the basement of the building the land around the site was cleared of large trees and brush, which were useless and considered a nuisance and a danger, the work being done by the Indians exclusively. Quite a number of large trees were cut down, trimmed and piled on the school property. I would suggest as a measure of economy that they be cut into suitable lengths for fuel for the new school. This work could be done by the Indians, who are anxious to earn money. I would not advise giving the wood to the Indians as it would create trouble among them.

Departmental Engineer.

November 12, 1935.

Memorandum: Doctor McGill.

Re: New Maniwaki Indian Day School.

I made an examination of a spring located near the new school, and beg to advise that the water is ordinary surface water, unfit for drinking purposes.

There is a well, some three hundred feet from the school, where the water appears to be safe. This well was dug down to a depth of 15 feet by the Indians, there being a good supply of water the year round. I would suggest that a well be bored to a depth of 25 feet, at a cost of about $100.00 including the pump, etc. I believe that the chances of getting a good supply of water are favourable.

I might add that the Contractor started the work last Thursday. I had an interview with the new foreman, whom I believe is fully qualified to supervise the construction of this building, which I expect will be completed before the Christmas holidays.

Departmental Engineer.

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Re: New Combined Day School and Teacher's Residence, Maniwaki, Que.

In accordance with instructions from your office a price was obtained from Mr. Wilfrid Lepine of Maniwaki for the completion of the above mentioned building, which offer I now beg to enclose herewith for your consideration, and which amounts to $4,329.48.

Although Mr. Lepine's offer stipulates that his price covers the entire completion of the building now in course of erection it is supplemented by a list giving a summary description of the nature of the work to be performed, as well as other conditions to which his offer is subject.

I am also attaching hereto a memorandum from our Departmental Engineer as to the progress of the work up to date, which gives an approximate estimate of the cost of the work remaining to be done to complete the building in question on condition that the work is carried out under the same arrangements as those first adopted, that is by day labour.

This memorandum also gives, in the penultimate paragraph, the reasons for the difference between the original estimated cost of the building, namely $6,500.00, and the present estimate of $8,600.00, which increase I believe could not be avoided under the circumstances.

Will you please advise me if Mr. Lepine's offer is to be accepted.

Deputy Superintendent General.
December 13, 1935.

Dear Sir,

With regard to the disposal of the old day school on the Hull Maniwaki Highway, Maniwaki Indian Reserve, which is about to be replaced by a new combined day school and teacher's residence, I understand that it is not possible for the band to secure a lot in the vicinity of the old school, where the building could be moved and used as a Council House.

In view of this fact I would request that you invite bids by public notice for the purchase and removal of this building from the school property, with the understanding that the site on which it is now located will be thoroughly cleaned and the old material removed.

The Department will send you in a day or two short specification as to the conditions to be complied with by the bidders, as well as the procedure to be followed in inviting the tenders.

Before proceeding with the matter, however, it will be necessary for you to advise the Indian Council of the intention of the Department, and in the event of the Council being in a position to arrange themselves, at their own expense, for the securing of a site and the removal of the old school within a month, I would ask you to advise the department to that effect with the least possible delay, giving your views and recommendations, when it will again be taken into consideration.

Yours very truly,

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Que.

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

The Department does not now supply double desks. The type we supply is the single school desk. We are aware that there were a number of double desks in the old school and also a number of single ones, which, no doubt, have been transferred to the new school.

I have to request that you will advise the Department the size and the number of each size of single school desks that will be required. You should state, also, whether any front and rear seats for the single desks are necessary. I am enclosing a page from a catalogue, showing the seating plan of a classroom. In stating the number of desks required, you should take into consideration the number of rows that can be placed in the room and the number of desks in each row. It is considered the double desks should be in the centre, with the single ones on each side. I would request that you give consideration to the seating plan enclosed and state definitely the number of new single desks, fronts and rear seats that are needed to provide seating accommodation for the children who will attend the school. When full information is received, the order for the supplying of the desks will be placed here.

For your further information, I would say that single school desks are manufactured in the following sizes:

| No. | Size |
|-----|------|
| 1   | pupils 16 to 18 years |
| 2   | 12" x 15" |
| 3   | 10" x 12" |
| 4   | 8" x 10" |
| 5   | 5" x 8" |

It might be advisable to discuss the matter of the desks with the teacher.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Encl.

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Que.
January 20, 1936.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 19th ultimo accompanied by a sketch showing the proposed site where the old school on the Hull Maniwaki Highway could be removed and used as a Council House, on the Maniwaki Indian Reserve, which site could be purchased for the agreed price of $25.00, I beg to advise that the necessary steps are now being taken for the acquiring of the above mentioned land.

In the meantime I would ask you to invite tenders from Mr. E. M. Gendron, of Maniwaki and Mr. Wilfrid Lepine also of Maniwaki for the removing of the building above referred to to the new site, as suggested in your letter of the 19th of December, in accordance with a specification outlining briefly the work to be done, that is the manner in which the building is to be moved, and its erection of new wooden sills, etc. If you think it necessary you might ask these contractors to accompany their tender with an accepted cheque as a guarantee that the work will be completed to your satisfaction. It should be mentioned in your specification that if the building is damaged during the process of removal that the contractor shall put it in the same condition as it was at his own expense. Duplicate copies of the specification should be sent here as soon as they are prepared for the records of the Department. In your specification provision should also be made that Indian labour is to be given the preference whenever possible, and the time given the contractor for removal should also be mentioned.

It might be advisable that you ask these two contractors to submit a separate tender for the removing of the office and small storehouse, which is now at the site of the new school, to some more convenient spot at the rear of the school lot, as understood with the Departmental Engineer when he last made an inspection of the new school building. It will be necessary, of course, for you to prepare a separate specification to cover this work giving a description of the new location of this building.

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Que.

Memorandum: Schools Branch.

I was lately advised that the surface coat of plaster laid on top of the gyprock in the vestibule of the new combined day school and residence on the Maniwaki Reserve, has fallen down, due I suppose to humidity in the building before the heating system was put in operation.

Dear Sir:

The Department has been advised that the surface coat of plaster, laid on top of the gyproc in the vestibule of the new combined day school and residence on the Maniwaki reserve, has fallen down. It is considered that a poor job was done by the contractor, Mr. Lepine, and you should arrange with him, early next spring, when weather conditions will be favourable, to renew the plastering and place it in good condition. Mr. Lepine should carry out this work without expense to the Department. Also, should the plaster become loose or fall off in other parts of the building, the contractor should make the necessary repairs. Please keep this matter in mind and arrange to have the repairs to the plaster carried out early next spring.

Yours truly,

Maniwaki, August 7th, 1936.

Sir:-

I beg to inform you that the Old Maniwaki School house is now removed from the School Ground. It would be advisable that some levelling of the School Ground be done, picking up the stones filling the holes and hauling sand or gravel to bank around the foundation to keep the rain water from entering the cellar.

It is also advisable that the Water-Closets be removed from the present site, they are too near the school and out of the teacher's view when in the classroom, they would have to be removed approximately 35 feet.

Of course only the absolute necessary work will be executed, and I recommend an expenditure of $50.00 for the above mentioned purposes.

I would refer you to Mr. J. D. Chene, Dept Engineer who is familiar with the facts.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I visited the Maniwaki Indian day School today and found that the following requirements were needed:

1.- Repairing of the water tank. Water was left in this tank during the Christmas holidays and busted it. It might be possible to repair this water tank or drinking fountain but I am not very sure of it. If it could not be repaired a new one would have to be furnished.

2.- At least four window screens for the school and one for the house should be furnished.

3.- The hot water boiler for clothes is also busted and should be repaired.

4.- One more empty barrel should be furnished for water or at least the one that is there should be painted and recleaned to be able to use it.

I also noticed that the toilets were in a very bad condition and were very dirty. The floors of the school were washed only twice since the month of November 1936. I understand that it is quite hard to keep the floors clean in the Spring with a bunch of children, but I really believe washing the floors...
once a month would not be too often.

Would you therefore let me know if these requirements are necessary and if so I will have them done as soon as I get permission.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa,
May 10, 1939.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant regarding certain requirements at the Maniwaki Indian day school I would point out for your future guidance that when submitting requests such as those contained in your letter you should give an estimate of the expenditure that will be necessary. I presume that it will not be costly to repair the water tank, purchase 4 new screens, a clothes boiler and 1 water barrel. You may, therefore, secure these.

You may arrange to have the toilets cleaned and forward an account for the work.

I note your remarks that the floors have not been washed since November, 1938. In this regard I may say that Abraham McDougall, the caretaker, is allowed an amount of $100.00 a year which is a much larger sum than is allowed at other Indian day schools throughout Canada. At the time of his appointment it was distinctly understood that he would carry out any duties required by the teacher. Either the teacher or yourself should instruct McDougall regarding the times at which the floors should be washed and if he does not carry out your instructions you should advise the Department and nominate some person else to do the janitor work at this school.

Yours truly,

J. E. Gendron, Esq.,

I have your letter dated May the 31st, 1940, asking me to get a refund from Mr. J.G. Nodon for $2.50 for money overpaid him on one alarm clock furnished for the Maniwaki Indian Day School.

I have checked Mr. Nodon's account with him and find that instead of being overpaid he has still an account of $2.50 against the Department.

On December the 16th, I sent you Voucher No. 182, in favour of Mr. Nodon to the amount of $2.50 for one alarm clock furnished to the Maniwaki Indian Day School.

On the same date I sent you Voucher No. 163, in favour of Mr. Nodon to the amount of $5.00 for one pair of glasses for Mrs. Jos Forbes, Barrière Band.

The total of these two Vouchers were $7.50 and Mr. Nodon has really received only $5.00 thus making a balance of $2.50 still owed him. If as your letter says there has been an error in the
Vouchers, I will gladly correct it, but I am at a loss to understand how it is that a voucher could have been made for $2.50 when the account for Mrs. Jos Forbes was for $5.00, therefore the voucher and the account did not correspond and you would have noticed it immediately.

Frankly I do not know what is the proper way to fix it up and I will await your letter letting me know what to do in this case.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of November the 2nd, 1944, concerning the repairs to the toilets at the Maniwaki and the Congo Bridge Indian Day Schools.

These toilets have not yet been repaired because when Mr. Doucet visited the Schools after Mr. Morris was here, this question was brought up and the toilets were visited by him. He there told me not to do any repairs on those toilets before I heard from the Department that he would take it up with the Department, that is Mr. Phelan, on his return. Yet I have had no word about the repairs to these toilets and the work has not been done.

I would add also that Mr. Doucet had ordered me to have a box made at a Spring at the Congo Bridge Indian Day School. This work was not done neither for the simple reason, that I could get no one on the Reserve to do it, although I have asked many Indians to box in this Spring.

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent.

INSPECTION REPORT - MANIWAKI INDIAN AGENCY

A visit was made to the above Agency on May 15 & 16th.

XX XX XX

SCHOOLS

Visiting the Maniwaki Indian Day School, I found the attendance to be quite irregular, with an average presence of a little over fifty per cent of the inscription; teacher, Miss Helen Brennan, is hoping that the Family Allowance Act will help to increase attendance. I took the opportunity to tell the pupils present, to tell their parents that unless they attend school regularly, the monthly allowance check will be cut down every month a child of school age is not attending school regularly.

This building is in great need of painting inside and outside, specially the outside which, in my mind will begin to deteriorate, as you can hardly tell that it has been painted.

XX XX XX

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, May 25, 1945.

Inspection report - Maniwaki Indian Agency

A visit was made to the above agency on May 15 & 16th.

SCHOOLS

I also visited the Congo Bridge school, in charge of Miss Kla Brazeau. The attendance is much better here, and the Indians in this section appear to understand better, the value of the Family Allowance, and apparently intend to take advantage of it. This school is in need of seats for six more children, and I recommend that same be supplied before the reopening of the school next September.

Referring to your letter of May the 30, 1945 concerning the painting of the Maniwaki Indian Day School and the Congo Bridge Indian Day School, I wish to inform you that I finally succeeded in getting a painter to go and visit these schools to make an estimate of the painting jobs.

The Congo Bridge Indian Day School would cost for painting the Inside and Outside, excepting the floor, which would need a new floor the sum of $165.00.

The Maniwaki Indian Day School would cost for painting the Inside and Outside, excepting the floor which would need sanding before oiling or varnishing as they are hardwood floors, the sum of $460.00. Moreover, this latter school would certainly need some repairs in the verandas before the painting job is done. I would estimate the veranda repairs at $40.00.

Regarding desks for the Congo Bridge Indian Day School the teacher tells me the medium size would be needed. The small size are too small for the children attending.

J.E. Gendron, I.A.

Mr. J. E. Gendron, Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Que.

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to painting the Maniwaki and Congo Bridge Schools. Owing to present conditions, we believe that only one school should be painted this year and I am inclined to feel that the Maniwaki School should be chosen.

It is noted that you have secured a quotation of $460.00 from a painter. I presume this covers both material and labour and would also mean the painting of both the interior and the exterior, with the exception of the floor, which would be sanded and then oiled or varnished. Please let me have a written tender from the painter from whom you secured the estimate. When submitting the tender, it would be appreciated if he would state the number of square feet of painting which is required. As soon as we receive the tender, it will be referred to the Director for his approval.

Philip Phelan,

Referring to your letter of July the 20, 1945, concerning a tender for the painting of the Maniwaki Indian Day School, I wish to include you herein this tender by Mr. Albert Archambault, painter of Maniwaki, P.Q.

You will remark that he is satisfied to paint all of this School both outside and inside same as it had been painted the first time for the sum of $460.00. It is estimated at about 4900 ft. square.

I had also asked this contractor to put a price on the painting of the shingle roof and you will see that he included this on his tender for the sum of $125.00. This roof needs to be painted very badly and I recommend it should be done. There is also the floor of the living room, as this floor is not worn it would be better to varnish it and it would cost $5.00. As far as the floor of the class room not included in the tender it should be oiled and he is satisfied to do it for $10. He claims it is too badly scratched for varnishing. The kitchen floor was painted when this school was built and it is included in his tender of $465.00

The whole tender would be as follow:
- $460.00 for painting all wood work that has been painted before both outside and inside.
- $5.00 for varnishing the living room in the residential part.
$10.00 for oiling the Class room floor.

All tenders made cover both material and labour and covered with two coats of paint.
